v.t. Scratch or pinch the hand, as an amorous overture see raraku'
v.t. Squeeze, work into a pulp. see rapu (ii)'
1.v.i. Go in different directions, disperse. I haere topuni tonu, kahore i korara see marara2.v.t. Beg.'
n. Greens, leaves of edible vegetables. He korare keha.'

1.v.t. Pluck or tear off a twig, etc. Koraria mai te peka o te rakau nei.2.Snatch up, tear up. Te pekenga atu o Te Oriparoa, koraria ake te tauare, rere tonu (Pi. 135, 4).3.n. Scape, or flower stem, of flax ( Phormium tenax). Ka pua te kowhai, ka ngawha te korari (M. 247). Me te wai korari (P. 71).4.The plant itself (in the north). He repo korari tenei (J. xx, 86). Korari tuauru, Phormium colensoi, a variety of flax.  '
a. 1.Clear, not turbid.2.Glistening, shining see purata3.Docile. Ki taku wahine kotungatunga, koratarata (S.) see rarata'
n. 1. Cyathea medullaris, a large treefern. = mamaku2.Young shoots of ferns.3.Turnip or similar roots. (mod.)'

a. Excited, agitated. Korawa hoki, i poapoaina mai ai ki nga mea ruarua nei (We are in a state of excitement since we have been tempted by these few things) (W.M. x, 199). kōrawarawaa. Rough, of the sea. Korawarawa te ngaru, ka rere te nehu.'
n. A moss used by women at certain times.'

1.ad. Not, with a future verb, the negative being preceded by e, ka, kei, or ki te (F.L. § 44–47)E kore korua e ngaro ki kona (T. 46).2.Following a reason why anything has not taken place or will not take place; in either case the negative will be followed by e (F.L. § 84)Te take i kore ai ia e tae mai (The reason he did not come).3.If strengthened by the addition of an adverbial particle, as ake or kau noa ake, it forms a strong negative with a past verb. Not at all A, kore kau noa ake te awa ra i whitikia e nga mano ra (T. 41). Ka whakatika ko Tangaroa ki te wehewehe, a kore ake i mawehe (T. 4). Kore kau noa atu he utu (Pi. 175, 4).4.a. No. Kore te hoe, kore te tata (P. 56).5.Used as a suffix to nouns it forms nouns indicating the absence or lack of what is denoted by the original noun. Ka mate ratou i te kai-kore i te wai-kore (They suffered from the want of food and water (T. 182).   And with adjectives in a similar negative sense. Mo te whenua kowhatu-kore tenei ki (This saying is for a stoneless country) (P. 107).6.n. Want, absence, lack of anything. I te kore tatata hei hoko parawai nekoneko (M. 97). Kihai i hamumu te waha i te whakama, i te kore kai ma te manuhiri nei (T. 186).7.Annihilation, destruction, nothingness. A, ngaro noa iho ki te kore a Hou, ratou ko tona iwi (T. 67).8.v.i. Cease to be. Kua kore te ika o tena wai inaianei. Me i kore, almost. Me i kore kua tahuri to matou waka.  9.Be gone, be absent, be lost. Tahuri rawa ake ona tungane kua kore a Hinekauirangi (G.-8, 27). Kua kore aku maka, kua kore aku mahe (W. ii, 128).10.Be destroyed, annihilated. Ka kino te whenua, kua kore a taua taonga (T. 96).  korekorea. Infantile, sterile. korengan. Non-existence, absence, non-occurrence, etc. He kitenga no matou i te korenga o te kai taua wahi i mahue ai. whakakore, whakakorekore, whākorekorev.t. 1.Cause not to be.2.Deny. Whakorekore tonu mai ia ki taua korero.'

n. The moon on the twenty-first and two following days, distinguished as Korekore tutahi, Korekore turua (or whakatehe), and Korekore piri (or whakapiri ki nga Tangaroa), as the case may be. The dates differ slightly in some districts. Kei hea te marama ? He Tangaroa-a-mua, he pau te Korekore (M. 392).'
1.a. Broken. Kua kore ke nga papa o te whare.2.n. Fracture. korengan. Broken place. korekorea. Tron, rent see pakore'
n. Trap, snare. whakakorekorev.t. Prepare the loop of a noose for snaring.'
n. Small canoe.'
n. Annihilation, complete extinction see kore (i)'

n. 1.Open country see koraha2.Sandal.3.A small canoe.4.a. Shrivelled, wrinkled, stunted. Mehemea ka kotia te mahunga o te wahine rapou ka korehe te tamaiti. kōreherehen. A superior variety of kumara, having a wrinkled skin.'

n. 1.Haze, mist, fog. Ko Tamaki nei e tauria ana e te korehu moana. E kore e kitea i te korehu tonga (M. 188). I wereohia pea ki te korehu tonga (S. ii, 69).2.fig. Regret, disappointment. kōrerehua. Dusky, dark, hazy. Ka korerehu te po, kaore ano i tino pouri. Rangi korerehu i marewa atu ai (M. 15). kōrehurehun. Light haze.'
n. Rootstock ofraupo (Typha angustifolia).'
n. 1.Coturnix novaezealandiae, New Zealand quail. He manu ohooho te koreke. To ana te pakake ki ro te wai, kume ana te koreke ki uta (M. 75). = koitareke, kokoreke2.Porzana pusilla, marsh crake.'
n. 1.Poll or back of an axe, etc.2.The upper end of a bone fish-hook, where it is attached to the line. see reke, rekereke, pureke'
kōrekorekoa. 1.Dazzled. Ka korekoreko oku kanohi i te ra.2.White. = korako'
see kore'
karemun. Plug of canoe, etc. Ka hoe ki waho ki te moana, ka unuhia te koremu.'
a. 1.Overflowing. Korengareng tonu mai te wai ki te taha o te kainga.2.Soft, boggy.3.Crushed, mashed. Ka korengarenga noa te hiku me te pane … i te ngaunga a te patu (T. 152).'
kōreparepa1.v.t. Split, tear. Koreparepangia te papa.2.n. Sling stone.'
kōreperepe, korepav.t. Split, tear off, rip up. Pera hoki ra te korepe nui, te korepe roa, te wahi awa, te totoe awa (M. 154). Ka puta mai a Tuna, ka korepekia te hiku (Tr. vii, 39).'
n. Archaic word for chief.'
n. Shallow swamp see repo kōreporepoa. Swampy.'
n. The hook of the tumu bird-snare. = rera'
n. 1.Gutter, tap, funnel, or anything to guide the passage of liquids.2.Diarrhoea.3.Some part of a canoe. Ka meatia nga korere e rua, kotahi mo tetahi taha, kotahi mo tetahi taha o te waka.'
see korehu'

1.v.t. Tell, say. Ka korero i te toronga atu o tana ringa ki a Paoa (T. 194). Whakarongo mai iana, kia korerotia atu e ahau ki a koe (T. 168).2.Address. Korerotia tatou e nga rangatira e noho nei; korerotia tatou!—Ka mutu, kei waenga e korero ana, he kiri kau (T. 101). Kei te korero i te korero o te toa (T. 157).3.v.i. Speak, talk.Ka noho raua ka korero (T. 169). Korero a whare and korere whenua, make peace, peace making. Tena pea koe te korero a whare na, kia houhia te rongo (S. 118). Mana ra koe e whakamau ki te kaha o te aio, o te rongomau, o te korero whenua (S.).  Korero rakau, think aloud.4.n. Conversation. Ka ahuareka noa iho a raua korero ki a raua nei (T. 169).5.News. Ka pataia mai te korero e Horowhenua (T. 199). Ka hui tera ki roto ki te whare i noho ai a Paoa, ki te whakarongo korero (T. 199).   Korero ahiahi, idle tales. Nga korero ahiahi a Hinewha (P.).6.Story, narrative, discussion. Ko te korero tenei o te toanga o etahi tangata o mua. whakakorerov.t. Make to speak. Ka whakakorerotia ano e ia, a kua nanu te reo (T. 42). kōrerorerov.i. Talk much or frequently, discuss. Ka korerorero ratou ki a ratou ano (T. 195). Hei korerorero, rongorongo ki reira (M. 414).'
n. A small canoe see reti'
v.i. or n. The call of the fern-bird. Kei te koreti te mātā i ro te roto.'
v.i. Trickle down, weep.'

1.a. Drifting about, adrift. Kia iri au i te waka korewa (M. 397).   Hi korewa tonu ai au, kaore e tukua te punga ki raro.2.n. Float for a net. = karewa3.Float of the outrigger of a canoe. Ko nga rakau korewa he rakau mama rawa; ko te take o te korewa hei tiaki i te waka kei tahuri.'

v.i. 1.Blink the eyes. Kaore e nge, korewha tonu nga kanohi o taua mokai (W.M. xii, 225).2.Raise the eyelids, as a secret sign. kōrewharewha1.v.i. Blink the eyes. Kua korewharewha nga kanohi, ka moe.2.a. Not sound (of sleep), with the eyes half open.'
n. Nestor meridionalis, parrot. = kaka see kōrīwhai'

n. 1.Native earth oven.2.Small basket or net. Ka noho te mokai kaka ki runga ki tana turuturu me tana kori kai. kokorin. Small bay. Takoto Whangaroa whaiti, kokori rerenga waka mai nohou ra, e Te Iwikau (M. 375). korikorin. Ranunculus insignis, a large species of buttercup.'

korikoriv.i. 1.Move, wriggle. Poto tonu ki roto o tana kupenga, kihai i taea te korikori (T. 143). Katahi ka ohooho noa ake, kua ngau katoa te ahi i tana koringa (J. ii, 215).2.Bestir oneself. Ka tae atu te karere ki te tini maia ra, katahi ka korikori te rauma-whitu ra (T. 157).3.Use action in oratory.'
n. Young kahawai (Arripis trutta), a fish see hapukupuku'
n. Amphibola crenata, a univalve mollusc. = titiko, karahu, takarepo'
n. Anthornis melanura, bell-bird. = korimako'
v.i. Sing, as birds. Takiri mai te ata, korihi te manu (M. 40). Korihitanga mai o te manu i te ata (M. 405). kōrihirihin. Tide. (R.)'
n. Porzana pusilla, marsh crake. = koreke'
n. Anthornis melanura, bell-bird. = mako, makomako, komako, kokomako, korimako, kokorimako, kokorihimako, kokorohimako, titimako, kopara, rearea, titapu, tutumako'
a. Covered with seaweed. Korimurimu ana nga kohatu, ka paheke see rimurimu'

1.v.t. Twist loosely. Is not = whiri2.n. Twist, hank, curl. He korino whitau.3.a. Twisted, curly, as hair. kōrinorinon. 1.Eddy, wake of a canoe.2.Mottled surface. Me he korinorino kokopu (P. 68). see rino'

1.n. Rapid. Ehara ko te wai o te korio (S.).2.Penis.3.a. Pale. kōriorioa. 1.Withered, wrinkled, shrivelled up, shrunk. Kua korioriotia nga kai o te rua.2.Burning, scorching. Kua heke te ra he kapura koriorio (P.).'

1.v.t. Cut, slice. I rarawe taku ringa i te piharoa hei koripi ake te kiri ra i awhi ai (M. 266).2.v.i. Turn sideways, of a paddle, etc. Kei koripi mai te hoe.3.Look sideways. I koripi aku mata te oranga Waimako (S.).4.n. Knife of obsidian or of shark''s teeth. Ka hoake a Whaitiri i te koripi, ka haea te puku o Tupeketi (Tr. vii, 41).5.Vagabond. He porangi te tangata ra, ka tahi; he koripi, ka rua; he kurapa, ka toru.6.Diarrhoea.7.v.i. Rise out of water, as the heavenly bodies. Kua koripi te marama (Po.).'

1.v.t. Whirl. I koripoa au e te wai o Titahi (M. 399).2.n. Eddy, swirl. Koripo marama, an expression for bad weather. He koripo marama kia tangi atu au (M. 250). kōriporipo1.a. Eddying.2.n. Wake of a canoe. see ripo'
n. 1.A cloak ornamented with black and white thrums of unscraped flax. Tatua ia te korirangi (M. 171). I te kore korirangi hei hoko parawai pakipaki (M. 97).2.Untwisted thrums of a mat.'
kōrireriren. Gerygone igata, grey warbler. Koriri takiri te ata, ko te manu kaore ka tino awatea (M. 432). = riroriro'
n. A mollusc, ? one of the Turritellidae.'
n. Muggy heat. Korire ana te rangi see rirerire 3.'
n. Immature fruit.'

1.v.i. Sprout. E koriro ake ana te tupu o te kapana.2.n. Leptocephalus conger, conger eel. = koiro kōriroriron. Gerygone igata, grey warbler. Nga tataeko, nga koriroriro, ia manu, ia manu (T. 29). = riroriro'
a. Cautious, alert. Kia korita, kei rokohanga e te kohuru.'
a. Unsteady, applied to a canoe.'
n. A variety of flax. (Tar.)'
v.i. Move in unison. Ka korite te huata ki runga, ka rere nga waewae see rite'

1.n. Heart or young unexpanded leaves of liliaceous plants.2.A dark-green opaque variety of greenstone.3.Soft outer part of shoulder-blade. = papa korito4.a. Flaxen, of hair. He ahu te uru o to tamaiti? Kapatau he uru korito, he karako, he uru ariki no Pipi (P.). kōritorito1.a. Unkempt, of hair.2.v.i. Glitter. see karito, rito'
n. Galaxias fasciatus, a fish. kokopu'
n. Nestor meridionalis, parrot. kaka, kōrī'

v.t. Desire, intend. Na wai te koronga ka tu ki roto ki Whangara? (P.). He koronga naku kia tae au ki nga uru kahika ki Ouru (M. 312). Ko te kai ra i koroa atu e te ngakau (M. 86). Korongata, reluctant, unwilling. Ko Kauanuhea korongata ki te haere (P.) see korou korokoron. 1.Throat. No te whakatanukutanga o te korokoro ka awhea mai ai e te hau o roto o te riu (T. 153).2.Geotria australis, lamprey. Tana kai, he korokoro (W. iii, 62). whakakorov.t. 1.Endeavour, intend. Whakakoro noa matou, te taea Patangata.2.Desire. Kia kite i te paura i te waipāta e whakakoroa nei e te tini.'

n. 1.Noose. Kei te hanga i nga koro o te rore (T. 19) see koromahanga2.The moon on the fifth day. = Akoro, Okoro3.Bay, cove.4. Metrosideros perforata, a climber. akatea korokoroa. Loose, slack. Korokoro noa nga tau o te kakahu. whakakorokorov.t. Loosen.'

n. 1.Old man. Ka patai mai te koro, “Ko wai ou hoa ?” (T. 201). Ka tatari te pa ra ki te reo o te koro nei kia oho (T. 202). see hakoro, koroua2.Father. Nga turipona o to koutou koro (M. 160).3.A term of friendly address to an adult male. E koro, hapainga nga toki nei (T. 51). kokoron. Old man. korokoron. Finger, toe, see koroiti, koro-matua'
kōruacolloquial pron. You two. Ma koro etahi, ma mou etahi.'

n. 1.Index finger. Ka hoatu e Mahuika ko te koroa (W. ii, 106).2.Finger in general. Ka mau ia i te ringa o Mahuika, ka poto nga koiti me nga koroa o tetahi, o tetahi, ka mau ia ki nga koiti o nga waewae (W. ii, 76).3.Second toe. see koiti, konui'
a. Tall, long see roa'
korowahan. Large curl of tattoo marks on the cheek.'
n. Steam.'
korowai'
koroamon. A small fish.'
korowatiton. Bowdleria punctata, fern-bird. see mātā (iii)'
a. Crooked see hape'
n. Shivering from cold or fear.'
n. 1.A kind of net, bag net. Ka noho taua wahine, ka ta i te korohe (Tr. vii, 41). see rohe2.Whitebait migrating up stream (Whang.).'
n. Turnagra capensis and T. tanagra, N.Z. thrushes. = piopio, koropio'
n. A cloak.'
n. Steam see kohengi'
v.t. Tuck up. Koroheiheitia ou, kei maku.'
n. Old man. Tera hoki te koroheke ra kua tae ki waenga (T. 201) see koro (iii)'
v.i. Spurt up.'

1.v.i. Start, wake. Ko te moe a te manu e korohiko noa ra i te ata hapara (S.).2.Sleep uneasily.3.v.t. Surround. Kua korohikotia e te taua i te atapo, ka huaki tokotoru i mate. korohikohikov.t. Surround. Te marama i runga ra, e, ka pau te korohikohiko e te whetu (M. 191).'
n. Hebe spp., shrubs. Na Hikuao te korohiko, ko te rakau i tunua ai te moa (M. 324). = koromiko'
korowhiti'
n. Haliotis australis, a univalve mollusc. = hihiwa'
n. Steam. korohuhūv.i. Boil.'
1.a. Reduced to shreds see hunga-hunga2.n. General name for cloaks having an ornamental border. Ka mau ki te korohunga, ka tatua.3.Ornamented border of a cloak.'
n. 1.Fruit of white pine ( Podocarpus excelsum). Hei te tau kori ra ano (P.).2.The tree itself. He iti te mokoroa e hinga te koroi (P.).'
v.i. 1.Wander idly.He aha tau e koroiroi nei, te haere ki te mahi? He taringa koroiroi, disobedient, inattentive. 2.Be confused. whakakōroiroiv.t. Hinder. He aha tau ka whakakoroiroi nei i te mahi ?'

v.t.  1 Desire. Matua te wairua ki te po, e koroingo ana ano (P.).2.n. Function held to welcome a newly born infant of highly ranking parents (Kah.) koroingoingoa. Puling, whimpering. He tangi koroingoingo see kōingo'
1.a. Wandering. He tira koroirangi (M. 395).2.n. Shimmering of atmosphere on a hot day; regarded as an omen.'
n. A species of duck, now extinct. korori'
n. A caterpillar.'
1.n. Little finger or toe see koro (iii), koiti2.a. Small. Ehara tenei motu he koroiti.'
n. An edible plant.'

1.n. Person, fellow; expressing familiarity or contempt. Tena ko tenei koroke kua mea nei ia hei tangata ki a tatou (T. 12). Heoi, noho ana te koroke me taua wahine (T. 135).2.a. Extraordinary, strange, out of the common. Ko te take tenei i ora ai tenei tangata, a Upokoiti, na tona koroke ki te rapu whakaaro see rereke3.Perverse.'
n. Constipation. (Po.).'

1.v.i. Speak, talk.2.Chatter of birds. Ka koroki to mann i te ata, ka maranga matou.3.v.t. Speak to, tell. Nana ahau i koroki ki te haere.4.v.i. Speak in a chiding manner = kohete(Po.). korokīkīv.i. Bicker, quarrel. = kowhete-whete 4'

n. 1.Hebe salicifolia, a shrub.2.Corokia buddleoides, a shrub. Also called korokio taranga.3. Cordyline pumilio, a plant.4.Blechnum capense and B. vulcanicum, ferns.5.Turnagra capensis and T. tanagra, N.Z. thrushes. = piopio, korohea, koropio'
v.i. Ka korokoroko te ika i hiia e Maui ka ea, ka whakawhenua, ko Te Ika a Maui (Tr. vii, 39). '
see koropeke'
n. Girella cyanea, blue fish. = karokaropounamu'
a. Trifling, unimportant. Waiho ki a wai a taua karakia korokororiki nei ? (M. 63).'
see koroua'
see korowai'
n. Clathrus cibarium, a netlike fungus.'

1.n. Noose. Kia ngaro rawa te upoko ki roto ki te koromahanga nei (T. 19).2.v.t. Tie in a bow or loop, tie with a slipknot.3.Make a snare. Nga wahi katoa e ngaro ai te taniwha ra ki roto ki nga koromahangatanga o nga taura (T. 151).   Katahi ka koromahangatia nga mahanga mo nga kawau. see koro (ii), mahanga'
kokoromahun. Steam.'

1.a. Suppressed, stifled (of feelings, etc.)2.v.t. Bear with fortitude, suppress one''s feelings, etc. E te mate i a au, e koromakina nei (S. 71).3.Be fully intent upon an object, pursue with all one''s mind. E taea iho e te iwi te koromaki, te hanga ka tauaki ? (M. 279).'
twitching of the limbs; regarded as an omen. Engari taku taha e kai koromaki ana (S.). koromamaki, whakakoromaki = koromaki 2+3'
n. Anthornis melanura, bell-bird. = korimako'
n. 1.Thumb, great toe. Kotahi i toe, ko te koromatua (T. 24). Ko nga waewae o Hotunui he piko te koromatua (W. iv, 30).2.Chief. E ora ana ra nga koromatua hei kauwhata i te riri (M. xcix).3.Penis.'
1.n. Barnacle.2.a. Anxious.'
a. In loops, coils, or kinks. whakakoromekev.t. Coil or loop up.'
koromemengea. Crumpled, curled up. He wa kareao kau taua ara, koromengemenge tonu, tautau tonu (Ha. 111).'
n. Hebe salicifolia, etc., shrubs. He koromiko te wahie taona ai te moa (P.).'
Hebe parvifloraand Pimelea longifolia, shrubs.'
komingomingov.i. Twist, curl, writhe.'
koromiromirov.i. Whirl, swirl.'
n. Muzzle, gag see mōkā'
n. Hebe salicifolia, a shrub. Ka haere ki roto ki te wahi ururua, peka puhou, koromuka, karamu (T. 79). = koromiko'
v.t. Rub off. = komuru'
komutun. A calabash with top cut off and used as a lid. Na wai te koromutu huahua ? —No te hoenga ka makere te koromutu hinu a Kahu.'
n. Modiolaria impacta, a bivalve mollusc.'

1.v.i. Lie broadside on. E rite ana ki te kararehe maori e koronae ana i te ahi (P. 106).   Kua koronae te waka ki uta.2.v.t. Drink out of the hand.3.n. Grass or fern leaves placed round the native hangi to prevent the food falling off the heated stones.4.Stile. see koropae'
a. Crooked see nuke, konuke'
see koro (ii)'
see koro (ii)'
a. Benumbed see kongenge'
n. 1.Food offered to the atua and eaten by the tohunga in the ceremony of pure.2.Some object used as a talisman. Mauria tenei hei koropā mou.'
n. Bolt, peg, for fastening a door.'

n. Band of woven leaves to line an earth oven. = kopae, koronae koropaepaev.t. Make a lining as above. Ka karia he rua, ka koropaepaea a roto ki te kaponga, ka hoatu nga kai ki roto, ka kiia tena he koputu kai.'
1.v.t. Fillip.2.v.i. Shoot up. Ka koropana ake te tupu o te kapana. toropana'
Naku koe, koe tauhoro iho ki te whare koropana, tata ki te wai (M. 251). '
Religious rite. Na te aukume i koro-patutia (M. civ). Na Koikihi ra i koropatutia ki te koropatu taniwha (W. v, 93) see korotapu'
v.t. Turn a canoe by use of a paddle near the stern, reaching out and drawing the paddle towards the side.'
v.t. 1.Repress. He mate hiakai, ka taea te koropehu.2.Break. Akuanei koropehua ai to rakau.'
v.i. Twist, wriggle.'

1.a. Having the limbs doubled up. Ko te moe tenei a te manu, me koropeke (M. 34). Koropeke ki te whare, ka tihohe au ki te mahi kai (M. 251).2.v.i. Curl up, double up. whakakorokoropeken. Contraction of the limbs.'
n. 1.A fish.2.A spiral ornament of bone or greenstone. = kotuku'
n. A spiral line in tattooing.'
n. Ring, loop, bow.'
kopihan. 1.Pit.2.Pool.'
Tena ko tenei e koropiha ana maua. '
n. Small aperture in front wall of a house immediately below the ridge-pole; a smoke vent (Kah.) see pihanga'
1.v.i. Bow down, kneel.2.n. Loop.'
n. 1.Turnagra capensis and T. tanagra, N.Z. thrushes. = korohea, piopio2.Blechnum capense, a fern. = Kiokio, korokio'
n. A design in wood carving (Kah.).'
1.a. Built with wrought timber. He whare koropu.2.n. Storehouse. Kotahi koropu taewa.3.Small makeshift hut.4.Name of the fifth act in the game ruru (Tr. xxxiv, 67).'
1.a. Double, twice told. Ka tahi koropu. = pū (ī-5) 2.v.i. Curl over. Ka koropu te ngaru, ka whati see pū (ī) .'
n. Gaultheria antipodaand other species; shrubs.'

1.a. Concealed. He kino koropuku.2.Swollen.3.Solitary, lonely. Moe mai Parau i te moe koropuku; tenei ano au hei hoa mou (S. ii, 85). Kia koropuku au, te moe a te kereru (S.). Ka koropuku te moe, ko te moe a te manu, ko te rite i ahau (S.).4.Rounded, convex. Te taha koropuku o te hoe (Po.).5.v.i. Move stealthily.'
1.a. Soft, porous.2.Decayed. Kua koropungapungatia te rakau.3.n. Pumice stone.'
n. A fish. Kia ea ake to ika he koropupu, he manga ro wai ata te ika o te mara (M. 80).'
v.i. Bubble up, boil. Te ingoa o te puna, ko Oringi, e koropupu ake ana i te whenua (T. 183).'
n. Hole see koputa koroputaputaa. Full of holes.Hence mate koroputaputa, smallpox.  '
1.n. Eudyptula minor, blue penguin.2.a. Grey. Kia kotahi te pokai pango, kia kotahi te korino korora.'
n. A cloak, similar to korawai.'
n. A black stone used for making weapons.'
kōrorirori1.v.t. Stir round.2.Distort, disfigure. Nou anake te taka-taka i kororia ki te rau o te tewhatewha (M. 402).3.a. Twised. He rakau korori.4.Perverted. To kupu e tika ana, to mahi korori ke.'

n. 1.A land bird, said to be extinct. E tangi ana te korori, te korora (S.). = koroire2.A planted used as a dye. I pania ki te korori ra i te ngahengahe, i tahekea iho he raukawa kei taku tinana see tororire'
a. 1.Black, dark. Kua kororiko nga kanohi, kua pokepokea e te pango see wheriko2.Angry, lowering. E tama ! Kua kororiko katoa ou kanohi. (Said to an angry person.)'
n. Plaited band for lining an earth oven. = koronae, kopaepae(Tu.).'
n. Whirlpool, eddy.'
1.n. Haliotis australis, sea-ear, mutton-fish; a univalve mollusc. = kara-riwha2.a. Chipped, gapped. Kua tohi te marama, kua kororiwha see riwha'
koroan. Index finger.'
n. Cut-water; a toy (Tr. xxxiv, 48). = purorohu, porotiti'
n. Hole, pit.'
n. Outer facing of the lintel of a door. = korupe'
ad. Askance. Ka titiro korotaha te hoiho ki te ngaru = kotaha'
n. A species of duck see korotau, kotai'
n. The name of a constellation. Ko te pakanga tena i marere ai nga unahi o Takero, ka taka iho ki raro, koia a Korotakataka, whetu, koia te paenga o te Mangaroa.'
n. Pit for storingkumara, etc.'
n. Jumping-jack; a toy.'
n. Food for the atua or the tohunga. Ka whakarewaia, ka kore o korotapu, o kai ariki (S. ii, 78) see koropatu, which White takes in above sense in W. v, 93.'
n. A species of duck.Kei whea korotau ka ngaro nei (M. 235) see korotai'
v.t. Squeeze, crush. Apopo ia ka korotetia e te ringa patuki tuatara o te kainga o Te Wahineiti see kotē'
n. Fish trap or corf.'
v.i. Chirrup.'
a. Spotted, speckled. = kotingotingo'
a. Prickly see tio'
n. Teredo antarctica, ship-worm, a small mollusc. = korotupa'
n. 1.Spot see tiwha2.Process of countersinking pieces of shell in carved objects. korotiwhatiwhaa. Spotted.'
1.n. Lake, pool.2.a. Deep.'
n. A garment. E rua nga kahu Maori, he uhipuni tetahi, ko Paekawa, he korotoi tetahi, ko Te Uawhiti. = toi'
n. Anus. = kotore'
a. Desirous. E korotu ana ki te haere. Tukua mai ki a au he ngakinga mate; taku korotu atu i konei, ma Te Paraha (M. 101) see koro (i)'
n. Skull.'
v.i. Stoop.'
a. Emaciated, haggard see korotu (ii)'
korotuketukea. Crooked, bent see tuke, koronuke'
n. Teredo antarctica, ship-worm, a small mollusc. = korotipa'
v.t. Preserve game in fat. He wahine nana i korotutu see kōtutu, tutu'

1.n. Desire. Tikina mai au, whaka-wairekatia kia hoki ake ai te korou ki te ao (M. 52).2.Energy, spirit. Korou-kore, listless.  3.v.t. Purpose, desire. Ko te wahi tena i koroutia ai e au kia haere ki reira.—Na wai te korounga ka tu ki roto ki Whangara ? (P.). He mea korou koe maku nei ki te whare (S. 74) see koro (i)'
n. 1.Channel. Kia tika ki te korou.2.River. (R.)'
korokorouan. Old man. Uia mai ra to koroua hamu, i tupu ki hea te kawai o te hue ? (M.M. 194). Ko to te Maori mate kia korokoroua rawa ka mate ai.'
koroahan. 1.Tattoo marks on the cheeks.2.A pattern of carving.'
korokorowain. Cloak ornamented with black twisted thrums.'
v.i. Snore. E tangi, e te ihu, koro-waru ana i te moenga.'
koroatito'
a. Bent, bowed see whana'
n. Steam see whanake'
n. Engraulis antipodum, anchovy, a fish. (Tr. v, 270). = kokowhawha'
a. Blowing in whirls or eddies see awheo, tawheo'
n. Steam.'
1.v.i. Whistle. Mehemea ka korowhio te kiwi, penei me te korowhiti, a he tane tena.2.n. Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus blue duck. see whio'

korohiti1.a. Bent round, like a hoop.2.v.i. Spring up suddenly from a stooping position. Nga tama korowhiti a Tangaroa a poetical expression for kanae, mullet.3.Whistle through a bent finger. Me whakatangi te korowhiti ki Tauritoatoa ki a Te Ngahue (M. 87).4.v.t. Jerk, give a sudden impulse to. Na te pou koa i korowhiti i rere ai i te hau (S.).5.v.i. Twitch, start. Korowhiti ake ana te tau o toku ate (W. v, 18).'
v.t. Throw see porowhiu, whiu'
korohihiv.i. Boil up, spurt up.'
kōrūrūv.i. Shake. Kanui te korū o te whare nei i te hau see ru'

1.a. Folded, coiled, looped. E koru ana te whakaheke: kia maro tonu.2.n. Fold, bight, loop. Nekehia mai te koru o te aho.3.A bulbed motif in carving and scroll painting. kokoru, kokorutangan. Bay, indentation of the coast. Tenei ka noho nga kokoru ki te Kouamua (M. 136). korukorun. Wrinkle, looseness of the skin as in aged persons.'
n. Colensoa physaloides, a plant korukorun. Elytranthe colensoi, a parasitic plant, when in flower, or possibly strictly only the flowers.'
pron. 2nd pers. dual. You two. He aha korua te haere tahi mai ai? (T. 27).'

kōruaruan. 1.Hole, pit. Ka rere iho taua wahine nei ki roto ki te koruarua (T. 13).2.Canoe. Kei mohio atu te titiro ki te korua e hoe ana o Hikareia (M. 420). whakakōruav.t. Hollow out, excavate.Whakakoruatia te takotoranga mo te wai.'
a. Puckered up, wrinkled. Kua koruhetia te tangata nei.'
v.t. Shake vigorously. Koruiruia nga riwai kia ngahoro ai nga ngarahu see rui'
a. Cloudy, overcast. He rangi koruki see koruku, kauruki'
kōrurukua. Cloudy see koruki'
n. Outer facing of the lintel of a door Nga tokotoko, te korupe, te paepae (M. 394). = kororupe'
v.i. Change, veer round. Ka korure te hau. kōrurerure1.v.t. Shake, stir up.2.n. Female of Acanthisitta chloris, rifleman, a wren.'

1.a. Wrinkled, puckered.2.Cloudy, overcast see ruru3.n. Shadow.4.Apprenhension. Tau rawa te koruru o te mate ki a koutou.5.A game played with stones. = ruru(Tr. xxxiv, 67). korurukia. Cloudy. = koruki. kōrurururua. Hanging in folds or loops, slack. Kia maro te taura, kauaka hai whakakorurururutia mai.'
n. Figure placed on the gable of a house (J. v, 149)'
see koruku'
kokorutangan. Bight, bay. see koru (i)'
a. Wrinkled, puckered. kuwhe-whewhewhe.'
v.i. Open, crack, gape. Kotā ana te papa i te ra.'

n. 1.Cockle shell.2.Anything to scrape or cut with.3.A rope of human hair used in certain rites. Tenei mea te kota he mahunga tangata i whiria ai hei whakaheke.4.Excreta of wood-boring insects, grubs, etc.5.Sawdust. (mod.)6.Fragments of charcoal from burnt brush. Katahi ka tahuna te manuka, ka hora nga kota kia piri te kota ki runga ki te whenua. kōkotan. 1.Amphidesma australe and Paphies novaezealandiae, bivalve molluscs. Akuanei ko te whakatokanga o nga kokota i mauria atu e Kahu ki roto ki te wai.'

1.A large species of mussel.2.A mark made at cross-roads to show which road has been taken. Te Kokota, Aldebaran, a star; or perhaps a constellation containing the star. Ko te Kokota, he whakaatu i te awatea tana mahi see Kokouri kotakotan. 1.Cockle shells.2.Chips, shavings, scrapings. Kia kitea mai ai e Manaia nga kotakota waruhanga tao e mau ana i a ia (T. 118).3.Verreo bellis, banded pigfish.'
n. Alluvial soil.'

1.n. Sling for throwing stones.2.Rod with cord attached, for throwing a dart. = totaha. Kotaha kurutai, a stone weapon attached to a cord by which it was recovered after having been thrown at the enemy. Ka tutaki a Pahau ki a Tauira-iti, a ka whiua te kotaha kurutai a Tauira-iti ki a Pahau; ka hopukia taua patu e Pahau, a ka kumea te taura e mau ra i taua patu e Pahau (W. iv, 93).3.Part of a chief''s head-dress, consisting of a fillet in which feathers were stuck. Ka mutu te heru, e tia ana kia herea te kotaha, e rima tekau o nga kaka, maka iho te kotuku, te huia hei whakapaipai mona (T. 138).4.ad. Sideways, askance. Ka titiro kotaha ahau (S.).'

num. One. Used adjectively and predicatively, but not in counting or as an ordinal.Horo maunga ki tua, pakira ki tangata kotahi (P.). Kotahi rawa te mea i kitea e au (T. 16). Toku kotahi , etc., myself alone, etc. Whakatika mai ki runga, taua ka whawhai; tou kotahi, toku kotahi (You by yourself, I by myself) (T. 77) see tahi whakakotahiv.t. Unify, make one. Ka oti enei whakaaro, katahi ka whakakotahitia kia whawhaitia he utu mo ta Raumati kino ki a Te Arawa i tahuna ra ki te ahi (T. 82). kōtahitahia. Few. Kua whiwhi i te pu kotahitahi i taua wa (W. v, 87).'
n. A bird.Kia marama au te titiro ki te kotai e rere mai nei na runga tonu mai o Waihi (S. ii, 37; M. 167) see kotaiahu, korotai'
n. Anthornis melanura, bell-bird. = korimako'
a. Brackish, unpleasant to the taste. Kaore hoki te kotaitai o taku waha i te inumanga i te Wairaro o Nuku see tai'
a. Round. = potakataka'
n. Brassica campestris, wild turnip. = pohata'
kōtamutamuv.i. 1.Open and close the lips repeatedly. Tohungia ki te waha, ka kotamu nga ngutu (M. 322).2.Flash frequently. He aha te uira e kotamutamu nei ?'
n. Breeze. = kotengitengi see matangi'
a. Cool see kutao, matao'
n. Alluvial soil, silt see kotae kōtaotaon. 1.Slight ripple.2. Kōtaotao hauwai, cool breeze, cool air.'
v.t. Irritate, provoke see whakatara kōtaratara1.n. Dance of triumph.2.Olearia ilicifolia, a shrub.3.a. Prickly.4.Piercing, keen. He tonga kotaratara see mataratara'

1.a. Loosened, untied.2.n. A long band of woven flax, about 6 in. wide, wound round the body of a chief as armour in battle. Ko nga patu … i titia iho ki roto i nga tatua kotara (J. xix, 200). = tātua kotara see tātua pupara3.A fern, the leaves of which placed in water formed a perfume. Taku hei kotara (M. 196). kōtarataran. 1.Fry ofkoheru, Decapterus kohera, herring scad.2.Pudenda muliebria.'

kōtaretaren. 1.Halcyon sanctus, kingfisher. E rere, e rere, e te kotare ki runga ki te puwharawhara (M. 29).2.Front lock of hair left long when all the rest has been cut short.3.Stage, projected from the fence of a fort, and slanting upwards, used for purposes of defence and as a lookout. E whakahua ana nga kaimataara i nga whakaaraara i runga i nga kotare o te pa.4.Pole on the gable of a rua kumara to hold back the thatch. = kotauranga5.fig. Beggar, sponge. He kotare koe (P. 24).'
n. Halcyon sanctus, kingfisher. = kotare'
n. A species of eel.'
n. Bowdleria punctata, fern-bird. I te ata ka haere nga tangata ki te patu kōtātā. = mātātā'
a. Split. Kahore tonu tena kia ngawha; ka kotata ano ia see matata'
n. 1.Young shoot of pirita (supplejack) or rarauhe (fern).2.Fresh root of fern from which the shoot springs see koata'
Na Mahuki ano i tuku kia haere ra, he kotau ano i kohau mai ai.  kotaurangan. Post on gable end of a rua kumara. = kotare kotautauv.i. Slope. Ko te wahi o to kainga e kotautau atu ra ki te wai.'
n. Young fruit of gourds. Mehemea ka makuru mai te hue, e paku ana, he kotawa. kōtawatawan. A mollusc.'

1.v.t. Squeeze out. Kua kotetia te wairua ki waho.2.Crush, mash see korote3.n. A form of karakia for bewitching.Ka maka atu e Maia ko te hura, ko te kote, ko te tapa, ko te matawha. kōtētēn. Schefflera digitata, a shrub. = patatē'
kokoten. Tattoo marks on the cheeks above putaringa and paepae. kotekotev.i. Make a smacking noise with the lips see ngote, mote'
a. Pale. Kotea tonu te moko; kihai i mangu. He kiri kotea, an albino  see tea'
a. Blunt.'
num. One. A local substitute for the word kotahi while the latter was tapu. No longer used.'
n. Gentle wind.'
1.n. post, pole. Me te koteo mau kupenga (P. 71).2.v.t. Make fast to a pole.'
n. 1.Swelling see tetere2.Diarrhoea.'
n. Potatoes steeped in water.'
1.v.i. Whisper.2.Murmur, grumble. He aha koe i kotete ai?3.Prate, chatter. Whakarere marire te kotete a te ngutu (M. 233).4.n. Shoot of potato, etc. kōtetetete, a . Chattering, talkative.'
v.i. 1.Spurt out, flow.2.Come into bloom, of plants. Ka pua ra nga taewa, ka koti.'

kokoti1.v.t. Cut in two, divide. Kotia te pu, waiho i kona; kotia te kauru, waiho i kona (M. 355).2.Interrupt, cut off, so cut across the path of any one.He māroro kokoti ihu waka (P.). He tamaiti kokoti tau, a child prematurely born. 3.n. Tattooing on the cheeks. kotingan. Boundary line.Kei runga matou i te kotinga moana e mihi kau atu ana ki a koe (that is, cut off by a stretch of sea). kokotin. Ambuscade, intercepting party. Also called kokoti moe roa. Heoti ano hoki ka rite nga kokoti a te iwi o Manaia (T. 119). I te ata ka haere mai te ope a Ngati Kahu-ngunu, ka whakanohoia te whakamoe kokoti. kotikoti1.v.t. Cut to pieces. Hei reira ka kotikoti ai i te ika nei (T. 22). I muri iho i te kotikotinga o nga makawe (M. 420). Mate kau ana ia, ka kotikotia e taua iwi, ka kainga (T. 40).2.Divide, lay off boundaries. Katahi ka tukua mai etahi tangata … ki te kotikoti haere mai i uta i Tauranga (T. 75). Haere pai ki te kotikoti kainga mo koutou (T. 82).3.n. Barrier, dividing fence, boundary. Ko ia to tatou kotikoti tiriwa (Sh.T. 190).4.a. Separated.5.Striped. Kotikoti ana ki te pango, ki te whero, ki te ma.'
n. A flat weapon of hard wood or bone, a form of mere, so called from the blade being lobed. I haere katoa nga mere pounamu, nga kotiate, nga patu paraoa (T. 153) see ate'
kōtihetihen. Notiomystis cincta, stitch-bird. see hihi (i), tihe (ii) Kōtihe-wera, the male bird.  '
v.i.  Break off short . Ka kino ta taua rakau, kua kotihe noa iho.—Ka mahia te muka, na ka kotihe, na te makuhane i wheraka ai. kōtihetihea. Brittle.'
kōtihitihin. Top, summit see tihi'
n. 1.Finger, toe. Kaua e tukua katoatia ou kotikara ki roto o te ipu; engari ko te koroa kia matua tuku ka whakapa ai ki te mangai see matikara2.Finger-nail, toe-nail.'
see kotipatipa'
n. Calabash with the small end cut off so as to form a bottle see komutu'
1.a. Speckled.2.n. Young seagull, Larus dominicanus. = koiro'

n. Acanthisitta chloris, rifleman; a wren. Kia kata noa mai te kikitara, he kotipatipa, he kohurehure, ki-ki pounamu e tangi ana ki tona whenua ka tupuria nei e te maheuheu (S. i, 13). Note: Shortland, in his version of this song, gives kotikotipa, while Grey (M. 312)has kotikotipae, or kotikotipa e. see tititipounamu'
n. A variety of potato with purple flesh.'

kokotipū1.v.t. Cut off, intercept. Used particularly of a lizard crossing ones path, which was an aitua. Ka kotipu te ngarara, hei mate moku (J. vi, 44; vii, 134.)2.a. Cut short, blasted. Te kumara kotipu o te mara o Tumoanakotore (P.). He tau kotipu, or he tau kokotipu, a year with an early winter see koti'
1.v.t. Tilt up.2.v.i. Come above ground, sprout. Ka kotira te mara merengi.'
n. Fishing rod. (R.). = matire'

1.v.i. Go or come one at a time. Kotiri marire te haere a te hanga nei. Te ao uru e kotiri ra (M. 418).2.Start suddenly in sleep; regarded as a bad omen. = takiri3.v.t. Plant fresh kumara in the place of those that have failed. = tiri4.n. Meteor. kōtiritirin. 1.Meteor. Me te kotiritiri. (Said of a person going frequently to and fro.)2.A game played with light sticks weighted at one end, which are made to bob up and down in a pool of water.'
n. Girl. Mehemea he kotiro, me waiho te ingoa i a Pare-tuahu (T. 136).'

v.i. 1.Move aside. E kotiti ana ki tahaki.2.Be distorted or displaced. Kei kotiti i a au etahi o nga tatai. kōtītitiv.i. Wander about, be irregular. kōtitititin. Acanthisitta chloris, rifleman; a wren. = tititipounamu, kohurehure'

1.n. North wind. He kotiu ra ko te hau (M. 382) see kō (iv)2.v.i. Dart or swerve, as a kite. = tiu kōtiutiu1.n. Rhipidura fuliginosa and R. flabellifera, fantails. = tirairaka2.v.i. (freq. of kotiu.)Dart or swerve, as a kite.'
n. Headache.'
1.a. Spotted.2.ad. Here and there. see tiwha'

a. Loathing, averse. E hoa, he koto koe ki te kai nei. kotokoto1.v.i. Trickle, drop.2.a. Small, of no account. Kotokoto kau a tatou kai.3.v.t. Pull up. No te korenga e mau wawe he ika i tana matau … katahi ka kotokoto a Kahu i tana aho.'

v.i. Sob, make a low sound. Ra te tai uru ka koto ki te awa (M. 20). Nga tai e koto i roto o Tatara (S. ii, 81) (Tah. ''oto.) kotokotov.i. 1.Sob. E hine, tangi kino, tangi kotokoto ki to moenga nei (S.).2.Squeak, cackle, make an inarticulate sound. E kotokoto ana te Kiore.'
n. 1.The pole along the after edge of the sail of a canoe.2.The rope attached to this pole, which was usually called waha.3.Projection. see tātākoto, tokotoko, titoko'
n. Leaves, etc., surrounding a native earth oven to prevent food from falling from the hot stones. = kopae, koronae'
kōkōtongan. 1.Cold south wind see kō (iv)2.fig. Misery.'
n. Window. = matapihi'

n. 1.Lower end; in a fish-hook, the bottom of the curve. Kōtoremakamaka, a pattern of lattice-work on walls of a house. Kotore-maunga, name of a stone, used for heating an earth oven. Kotore-puni, waka kotore-puni, a canoe formed of one piece.2.Tail, tail feathers of a bird. Me nga kotore huia te rakai ki tahi taha, ki tahi taha o te mahunga (Pi. 126, 3).3.Younger brother; used particularly in reciting genealogies. He kotore a Piwaka na Ahunuku.4.Outlet of a lake.5.Buttocks. Kia noho i taku kotore, kia ngenge te pakihiwi (P. 50).6.Anus.7.Actinia tenebrosa, sea-anemone.8.In the expressions kai kotore, umu kotore, which refer to the feast in connection with an aristocratic marriage.9.White clay. Ka tae a Tawhaki ki te uku, ara ki te paru kotore (W. i, 49).10.Nucleus of therua kōhā, from which the lightning seems to originate see kōhā11.Eye of the wind. Kia taka mai te kotore o te hau ki kona, ka paki.12.Shift, veer, change of wind. Apopo pea ka kotore te hau. kōtoretoren. Actinia tenebrosa, seaanemone.'
n. Porzana pusilla affinus, marsh crake. = kareke, koreke, koriki'
n. Token of respect, regard. E kawe ana i tana kotua ki a Te Aporotanga.'

1.ad. With the back towards one. E huri kotua ana te korero a taua tangata.2.n. A class of aitua, or ill omen, due to a house facing south, or a man turning his back on another (J. vii, 128). Mehemea ka anga te roro o te whare ki te tonga, he kotua tena, he aitua.3.So, ill luck. Ko te Aka-puahou he rua koha, ka mate tonu i reira tona kotuatanga.'

1.n. Glow preceding dawn. Oho rawa ake i te ata, e kotuhi ana te rangi see tuhi2.a. Hazy, smoky appearance of atmosphere.3.Discoloured, as streams in flood.4.Unpleasant, unpalatable, of food see motuhi'
1.v.t. Lace, fasten by lacing, interlace. Kotuia to tatou ra.2.a. Interlaced. Haere kotui, go arm in arm.  see tui'
a. Bent.He mea kotuke te kakau o te hoe see tuke'

n. 1.Egretta alba modesta, white heron. He kotuku rerenga tahi i te tau. (A proverb used of a visitor who comes rarely.) Kotuku-ngutupapa, Platalea regia, royal spoonbill.  Kōtuku-tawhiti and kōtuku-tea, varieties of potato. 2.Feathers of the heron. Maka iho te kotuku, te huia hei whakapaipai mona (T. 138).3.An ornament of greenstone or bone, consisting of a spiral with a head at the outer end. = koropepe4.A stroke or guard with the quarter-staff or tokotoko.'

1.n. Fuchsia excorticata, a tree. I whea koe i te ngahorotanga o te rau o te kotukutuku? (P.).2.The female totara (Podocarpus totara), a forest tree. He kotukutuku te ingoa o te uwha o te totara, he karaka te ingoa o te tane.3.v.i. Keep low to the ground see tautuku4.Be of the size of a fuchsia berry. Kua toro haere te kawai o te hue; kua kotukutuku; kihai i roa kua ringa tahi te hue.'
n. Stump. see tumu'
a. Docile. Ki taku wahine kotungatunga, koratarata (S.).'
v.i. Protrude, stick out see koure kōtureturen. A venereal disease.'

1.n. Hand net for catching fish see tutu (ii)2.Ladle for liquids. E tapu ra te upoko o Te Ruakeripo, te homai hei kotutu wai kaeo ki Te Kawau (M. 300).   Hoatu hei kotutu wai rearea ma Te Waru, kia inu raua ko tana kotiro.3.v.t. Dip up water. Ka haere a Hotumanea ki tahaki, kotutu wai ai mo te whaereere i roto i te rua one (W. v, 18).'
v.t. Preserve game in fat. see tutu (iii)'
Kotutu wahie, long pieces of firewood set up on end to form a cone-shaped pile and so allowed to dry. = whakatūtū wahie, potihi wahie'

n. 1.Knob, end, stump, protuberance.2.The bend near the point of a bone or wooden fish-hook.3.Bunch of feathers on rapa of a canoe.4.Knot, knob of hair when dressed on the top of the head.5.Clitoris. = kou o te tara koukou1.n. Crest of a crane, etc.2.v.i. Dress the hair in a knot on the top of the head. Ao ake te ra katahi ka whitiki, ka koukou, ka tia ki te raukawa, ka pani ki te kokowai, ki te ngarahu, ki te pukepoto hoki.'
koukou1.v.i. onomatopoetic Hoot. Tenei te ruru te koukou mai nei (M. 62).2.n. Ninox novaeseelandiae, owl, more-pork. So called from its cry. = ruru, peho'
koukou, kaukauv.t. Anoint, sprinkleKa uhiuhi ki tenei tua, ka koukou ki tenei manuka (M. 422). I koukou ai koe ki te wai o Urumangangana (M. cix).'
a. Good. E kore e kou ? see koi'
kouen. The upright posts supporting the beam of a heketua.'
kōuauan. Sprinkling rain. He kouaua, he au konehunehu, he tārū kahika.'
kuapoetical verbal particle Naku te mahi koua titiro i taku whanake-tanga (M. ci). Koua wehea e te tahakura ra (S.81). '
kouaha Roe of fish see toua'
n. Brachyglottis repanda, a shrub. = rangiora'
see koua (ii)'
n. Pagrosomus auratus, snapper, a fish. = tamure'
n. 1.Discharge before or with the āra (flooding) in childbirth.2.Gall-bladder.'
see koua (i)n. The upright posts supporting the beam of a privy'
v.t. Scull, steer with a paddle or oar. see ue (ii-3)'
kāukan. 1. Cordyline australis, palm lily, so-called cabbage-tree.2.Rootstock ofraupo (Typha angustifolia).'
n. 1.The part of a latrine behind the beam.2.fig. Abyss, death. Ko te kouka, ko te Po tonu tena, ko Hine-nui-te-po tena, mate tonu atu.'
n. Arripis trutta, a fish. = kahawai'
n. Dense dark bush. Ka rere a Kiore-ta ki te koukouoro, ka ngaro atu (W. ii, 28, where it is printed koukouaro).'
n. A fish.'
n. 1.Breastplate.2.Breastbone. Hoi to kouma, apopo e iri ana i te rakau i Totara-i-ahua see uma'
n. A contrivance for taking fish such as upokororo and marearea (Tr. xxxv, 79) see umu kōumuumuv.t. Whirl round and round. Kei koumuumua tatou e te ripo.'
1.v.t. Pull out, withdraw.2.v.i. Escape, slip away.3.Moult, of birds.4.Project, protrude. = koure5.a. Out of joint, dislocated.'
n. Firebrand see mounga'

n. Crayfish, Jasus lalandii and J. hugeli, (sea-water species), and Paranephrops planifrons (fresh-water species).He koura koia, kia whero wawe ? (P.). Koura papatea, Jasus lalandii,  Koura rangi, Grimethea gregaria, whale-feed; a minute crustacean.  kōurauran. Shrimp.'
n. A rough cape of undressed leaves of flax, used as a protection from the rain. = pake see koure'
v.i. Protrude, be prominent, stick out. Ka koure kau nei ko aku wheua anake.—Koure ana ou iwi ki waho see koture, kohure, ure'

kāurun. 1.Top of a tree. Taku ti kouru nui ka whati i te hau ripo (M. 215).2.Head of a river or valley. Ko Maungatautari kua tanuku, pakaru katoa tetahi taha, takoto atu ki Mangahoe, ngaro katoa te kouru o taua awa. Kia whakahekea ki raro, moe ai ki Mangarara, ki roto ki te kouru (T. 200). Kouru matangi, first puff of a breeze.  '
v.t. Thrust in, insert, submerge. I kourua ki te wai see uru'
a. Smooth, sleek. Ka koutata o paparinga.'
n. Coturnix novaeseelandiae, New Zealand quail. = koreke, etc.'
pron. 2nd pers. plural. Ye, you, of three persons or more. E koutou e haka ake nei, whakarongo ake koutou katoa (T. 65).'

1.n. Promontory, point of land, etc. Ko taua pa ra i te koutu o te kurae e toro atu ana ki te wharua. He koutu whenua, he tara wa moana (T. 43).2.v.i. Project, stand out.E koutu noa ake te puke i te raorao see utu (iv)(Ta. outu)'
v.t. Dip up. Koutuutua he wai ki roto ki te karaha see utu (ii)'
n. 1.Female of animals and trees.2.Term for female of koko bird (Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae) during the early summer, after which it was known as kokotea see uwha'
kōwāwāa. Neap. He tai kowawa.'

kōwaewae1.v.t. Divide, part. Auaka e kowaea te mahunga, hei pango tetahi taha, hei urukehu tetahi taha: auaka e kowaea hei mahora tetahi taha, hei piki tetahi taha. Kiri kowae, bark of totara and manuka.2.Pick out, set apart. Ka kowaea nga roi pai mana. see wae'
v.i. Yawn see waha (i)'
n. An ancient style of painting, for adorning the person and dwellings see Kowhai-whai.'
n. Young of kahawai (Arripis trutta), a fish.'
n. 1.Dry open gully.2.Any long depression or groove, not necessarily straight. kōwakawakaa. Grooved, fluted, marked with long depression or channels.'
v.t. Scrape. I kowania ki te pipi tairaki, kia rahirahi ai he panga mai mo to rakau. Aue ! see wani'
koanun. Cold.'

1.n. Plot of fern land in a wood.2.a. Living in the woods, wild. He tangata kowao te tangata i pahuatia ai te whare. kōwaowao1.v.t. Overgrow, choke. Kua kowaowaotia aku kai e te otaota.2.n. Phymatodes diversifolium, a fern.'
koara'
a. Coarsely plaited. Kete kowarawara, a coarsely plaited basket.'
n. Exudation. Me pani koe ki te koware taramea see ware (ii)'
koare'
kohariv.t. Crush. Haramai, e Te Tuki, kowari rawa koe i a au (S.). Another version reads kohari (M. 82). kowariwaria. Flabby, soft.'
koaron. A fresh-water fish.'
a. Having high steep banks. Ka tae ki te wai, ka kiia e tera, “Kowarowaro ana te wai.” Mau tonu iho hei ingoa, ko Owaro see waro'

koata1.a. Transparent see kawata2.v.t. Break down twigs to mark the way in the bush. kōwatawata1.v.t. Gleam, shine. Tenei pokurua mai, keiwha kowatawata te ra (T. 179). Kowatawata ana nga uru mawhatu i te hana o te ahi (Pi. 133, 11).2.a. Pleasant, agreeable to the taste. E reka ana te hua hou, e kowatawata ana.'
n. Fern root.'
n. Coturnix novaeseelandiae, New Zealand quail see koreke, etc'
n. Sphinx convolvuli, a moth. = wenewene'
v.i. Glow, gleam. Kua kowera te rangi see wera'
koera'
n. Young of kahawai (Arripis trutta), a fish.'
v.i. Shoot out, appear. Kua kowerowero te hina (of hair beginning to turn grey) see wero, werowero'
v.i. Converse, talk.'

1.v.t. Split open see ngawha2.Take out of the shell. Kowhatia he pipi ma tatou.3.v.i. Burst open, split. Ka kowha te rauawa.4.Flash like lightning.5.n. Cockles taken out of the shells.6.Summer lightning see kōhā kōwhāwhā1.v.i. Flash repeatedly.2.n. A bird. = tarewa'
whaean. '

kōhain. 1. Sophora tetrapteraand S. microphylla, trees. Ka pua te kowhai, ka ngawha te korari (M. 247). Kowhai ngutukaka, Clianthus puniceus; a shrub with handsome red flowers.    Kowhai taepa, a drooping variety of Sophora tetraptera. Katahi ia ka tuha i a ia, te upoko i te rata, nga maikuku o nga waewae i te kohai taepa, nga maikuku o nga ringaringa i te kohai ngutukaka.    Kowhai angaora and kowhai, tauiti, variety of kowhai.    He ua kowhai, spring showers, when the kowhai is in bloom. 2.Geum urbanum and Potentilla anserina, plants used for scenting oil. = kowhai kura3.A pattern of scroll ornament, different varieties being distinguished by the epithets kape tahi, kape rua, ngutu tahi, or ngutu rua.'
n. Painted scroll ornamentation.'
n. Some kind of ornament. Ko ana rau piopio, ko te kowhakararo, he mea i motu mai i te waha o te ika.'

1.v.t. Pluck off, tear off. Kowhakina ana tona maikuku hei ahi (T. 24).2.a. Ready to drop off. Kua kowhaki nga papa i te ngaunga a te mate. Me he manga rakau ano ko ahau e kowhaki i te hau. kōwhakiwhaki1.v.t. Tear off piece by piece. Kowhakiwhakia tetahi taro ma te kotiro.2.v.i. Flash frequently. A Hine-nui-te-po e kowhakiwhaki noa mai ra i te taha o te rangi (T. 28). see tiwhaki'

1.a. Bent, bowed, sagging.2.v.i. Moving the limbs restlessly, tossing. Ko ona pakikau kua pahuhu ke ki raro i te kowhananga a nga ringaringa, a nga waewae (Pi. 133. 11).3.Spring up in the mind. Ka kowhana i roto i te wahine ra te ngakau mate ki a Te Ponga hei tane mana (T. 167).'
v.t. Bend, allow to hang in a loopKaua e kowhanea; kia maro tonu mai. kowhanengan. Bay.'
kohanga'
a. Overcast with clouds. He ra kowhanga i werawera ai.'
n. Spinifex hirsutus, a plant.'
kōhaon. Hole. Na wai i ki tetahi kowhao kia purupuru, tetahi kia whakatuwhera (P.). Puku kowhao, dropsy.   kōwhaowhaon. 1.Basket for food. E rima kowhaowhao uwhi.2.Light showery rain.'
1.n. Astelia banksiiand A. solandri, liliaceous plants. Kowharawhara piri noa iho ano (M. 411).2.v.t. Split into strips. = toetoe'
n. A fresh-water fish.'
kōhatun. Stone, rock, Ka whakapupuni ia ki nga tauwharewharenga kowhatu o te waiariki (T. 133) see powhatu'
a. Dry and tasteless.'
see kowha kowhea = ko hea see hea (i)'
kōwhekawhekan. 1.Garment.2.Rag. I haere mai ahau ki tetahi kowhekawheka hei takai.'
koheke Kōwhekowhekov.i. Die out and blaze up again.'

kohera1.v.i. Open, gape, yawn. Ko te pipi, e kore e kowhera. Kowhera ou ringaringa (Loose your hold) (T. 50).2.Burst forth. Ka kowhera te uira i roto i nga keke o Tawhaki (T. 53).3.Flash, as lightning. Koi te kowhera i runga (M. 421).4.n. The jerking outwards of the arms or legs in sleep; a bad omen.5.The falling sideways of a mātāika. see whera, tuwhera'
1.v.i. Writhe, flounder. Ka kowheta te hiku (T. 151).2.a. Eager, impetuous. see takawhetawheta'
kōwhetewhetev.i. 1.Whisper.2.Murmur.3.Scold.4.Quarrel.'
a. Neap, of the tide see kowhiowhio'
a. 1.Split open. Ka kowhewhe noa iho te waka, ka puta te wai ki roto (T. 111).2.Shrivelled.'
v.i. Whistle. kōwhiowhioa. Neap, of the tide see kowheuwheu'
v.t. 1.Select.2.Whirl round. Kowhiria te manu kia mate ai.'

1.v.t. Pull up or out. Kua howhitia nga kumara a Te Raro.2.Pick out of the shell, cockles, etc.3.Select.4.v.i. Spring up or out.5.Appear, as the new moon. He marama mate ka kowhiti kei runga (M. 376).6.Start, twitch. Taku kiri kowhiti (M. 127). Ko te kowhiti, ko te matatu o te moe i te po, he aitua (M. lxxx).7.n. New moon. E titi te kowhiti, tiaho i runga ra (M. 187).8.Cockles removed from the shell.9.A fish.10.A cross stitch in reed panelling. kōwhitiwhiti1.a. Leaping, dancing, of water. Haere atu i tou huarahi i te wai kowhitiwhiti a Paretahuri (M. 227).2.n. Grasshopper. Kowhitiwhiti moana, shrimp.  3.Rorippa islandica, watercress.'
n. Basket or bag in which to collect paua, etc. Taia he kowhiu, ara he heki, e, ka ripi i te paua, ka ki te kowhiu. kōwhiuwhiu1.v.t. Fan, winnow.2.n. Fan.'
n. Pittosporum tenuifolium, a tree.'
a. 1.Silent see ngu2.Wearied, exhausted.'
1.n. A game. = ti ringaringa see ti (iii)2.v.i. Play at ku. E teka ana, e ku ana, e whai ana (W. iii, 7).'

1.v.i. Make a low inarticulate sound, coo, etc. Ka ku iho ai ki te hakoro (W. ii, 67).2.n. Said to have been a one-string instrument played by tapping with a stick. kūkūn. Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae, pigeon. Kua rongo raua i te kapakapa o te harirau o te kuku (T. 146). kukū1.n. Grating sound. Ka rongo a Kupe i te kukū o te takere o te waka (T. 116).2.v.i. Grate, make a grating sound. Whakarongorongo ana te taringa ki te haumi a te taurua e kuku nei (M. 243). whakakukūv.t. Beach a canoe. Ko te kei o te waka anake i whakakukutia ki uta (J. iii, 60).'

n. Showery unsettled weather, or a personification of the same. Aua tupuna, ko Whaitiri-pakapaka, kaore he au, ko te tangi anake o te whaitiri i te rangi; ko Ku; ka mao, ka ua, ka mao, ka ua. Ko Ku tena tupuna.'

kukū1.a. Firm, stiff, thickened, not fluid or watery. Ka patua te hinau, ka tatari, katahi ka pokepoke ki te wai; ka karanga mai tetahi tangata, “Kia iti te wai kia kuku ai.”—Kua kuku te kai nei.2.n. Thick liquid.'

pronominal suffix of the 1st pers. sing., which takes the place of ahau in combination with certain prepositions and definitives, forming the words āku, ōku, māku, mōku, nāku, nōku, tāku, amd tōku q.v '
kua Occasionally used Te rironga o Taupo i a Tuwharetoa, ku kore a Hotu i Taupo. '
akupoetical pron. My. Ku kiri kohiku ki tua te Rawhiti (M. 182).'

a verbal particle denoting that an action is completed, or a condition established, at the time indicated. Has, had, or will have, according as the time is present, past, or future.Katahi a Whakatau ka nanao ki te pito o tana taura, kua kuhua ra e ia ki nga pou o te whare (which had been inserted) (T. 62). Ko Paoa kua koroheketia, e toko-toko ana (Paoa has become an old man) (T. 198). Apopo, kua riro ia (Tomorrow he will have gone). see kia 7'
kūwahan. Gateway, entrance. Ka whaia ratou e te tangata whenua ki te kuaha o te pa, poroporoaki ai (T. 170).'
kūkūai, kūwai'
n. Said to be a garment made in very ancient times, of fur, hair, or feathers (Tr. xxxi, 635).'
n. Limosa lapponica baueri, eastern bar-tailed godwit.'
n. A sea bird.'
a. Cold.'
n. Young of animals. Me te kuao a te tohora nei te katete (T. 155).'
n. Sandal made of a single layer of flax.'
kuware'
kuwata'
v.i. Yearn. E hika hoki koe e kuatau noa nei (N.M. 1, 34) see Kuwata'
n. Beard.'
n. Delirium, delirious talk, as of sick persons. = kutukutu ahi'
koekoean. Eudynamis taitensis, long-tailed cuckoo. = kohoperoa'
v.i. Be assembled see emi'
v.t. Urge, press. I kuenetia i haere mai ai ahau. = kuhene whākākūenev.t. Beg. He whakakuene ta matou ki a koe, ara he kakahu mo matou.'
n. 1.A sea-fish, edible, small striped.2.A lizard. Ko te aria o Tamarau he kueo ngarara nei.3.Berries of Coprosma australis.4.A prickly plant.'
a. Moist, soaked. Te kueotanga o te whenua.'
kuweto'
kuwha'
kuhakuha1.a. Ragged, tattered. Kua kuha noa atu te kaka noa atu te kaka nei see hukahuka2.n. Fragment, scrap. He kuha kainga, a scrap of a dwelling place.  '

v.i. Gasp. I terenga-nui ai Tainui, Te Arawa, hei whakahoki mai i te mate o te aitu e kuha kau noa nei (S.). kuhakuha1.v.i. Pant.2.n. Mactra discors, a bivalve mollusc.3.Glycymeris laticostata, a bivalve mollusc.'
kuene'
kuwharu'
v. and v.i. 1.Gush forth.2.Make a rushing sound. see hi'
kuhuv.t. Insert. Me kuhi tonu mai ki roto i aku rehe (S. ii, 37).'
n. Limosa lapponica baueri, eastern bar-tailed godwit. = kuaka'

kuhiv.t. 1.Thrust in, insert. Tana taura kua kuhua ra e ia ki nga pou o te whare (T. 62).2.Conceal. Me kuhu e maua ki roto ki nga paru o te whare nei (T. 46).3.Introduce oneself into, join a company Haere mai, nau ano koe i kuhu noa mai, haere mai (T. 139).4.n. Cooking shed. kuhukuhun. Pig.'
a. 1.Short of food. Kahore ana tau kui (T. 160).2.Cold.3.Weak, cowardly.4.Stunted.'
n. Larva of Cicindela tuberculata, tiger beetle.'
1.n. Part of the cry of the pipiwharauroa. “Kui, kui, kui, whiti whiti ora.”2.v.i. Call the cry kui. Ka rangona te tangi a te pipiwharauroa, e kui ana.'

n. Woman. A common mode of address to a woman. E kui, kawea atu tetehi wai mo te manuhiri (T. 168). E kui, to tane ko mea (P. iv).   In some districts applied strictly only to a woman who is a mother. kuikuin. Old woman. Ka hia nga kuikui i hoki ki Toitoi? (P.) see kuia'
kuinga, kuikuingan. Streamlet, source of a stream. Te kuinga o te awa.—Ko nga wai kahore he rere ikeike puta noa atu ki runga ki ona kuikuinga.'
whakakuikuiv.t. Cause to scream, so tickle. = whakakoekoe'
n. 1.Old woman. Ka mea mai ano te kuia ra, “Ko Maui-taha koe ?” (T. 17).'
1.ka kuiatia (M. 157) see kui (i), hakui2.Mother, grandmother, or other elderly female relative. kuikuian. pl. Old women. I rongo ahau ki nga kuikuia o Otekura.'
n. Procellaria cinerea, grey petrel, and P. parkinsoni, black petrel. Ka whiti nei au kei Rurima, kei Mautoki, kei Karewa, te motu o te kuia (S. 95).'
1.v.i. Speak in a low tone. Tohe noa au ki te tikanga o te korero, kihai i kuihi te waha.2.v.t. Peel off, as bark. see toihi'
v.t. Desire. E kuika ana te turoro ki te kai mana. Hei whakawai-u mo te tamaiti e kuika nei (S. ii, 44).'
1.a. Cold. Kua koropuku te moe, kua rite ki ta te manu, ara kua kuiki, kua kore he tane.2.n. Cramp.'
a. Narrow, confined. He ara kuiti taua ara (W. v, 21).'
a. Cowardly, stupid.'
n. 1.Encumbrance, clog. Kukawhare, soot see kūtā2.A small species of mussel.3.n. Chips, as resulting from wood carving.'

1.n. Dry leaves of flax, ti, toi, etc. Ko nga kuka o te toi hai hukahuka.2.Abortion.3.a. Dry, applied to such leaves as above, I muri i tena ma te wahine anake e kai a muri iho, nga manu momona, taea noatia te kukatanga o te mahanga, ara te tawhitotanga. kukakukan. Dry epidermis of flax leaf removed in dressing. Whakatahaia te kukakuka, whakarerea te kukakuka (M. 222).'
n. Dark—coloured eel found in bush streams.'
n. 1.Chick of certain birds such as the bell—bird and parson bird, when first able to fly see pikari2.New potatoes, (mod.)'
see kū (iii) 2'
ad. Not. In local use, Taranaki, etc. = kahore'
kukū see kū'

1.v.t. Nip. Pass. kukua and kūngia.2.Draw together. Kukua te kete.3.Close, double up. Ka kukua te ringaringa, ka motokia ake ki tona ihu (T. 21).4.Hold the breath. Ka kaha rawa koe ki te kuku i tou manawa.5.n. Anything used as pincers, tweezers. Kuku o te manawa, that which has a hold on the affections. Kua whakaarorangi noa ake tona ngakau ki te ataahuatanga o Te Whatui—apiti, te kuku o tona manawa (T. 164).   Kuku—ā—mata, a method of carrying the huata spear.6.Mytilus planulatus, M. canaliculus, and other species of mussel. Ka kite a Paoa i reira i te kuku o Waiau (T. 196).   Kuku—mautoka, kuku—moe—toka, a species of mussel. Katahi ka haehaea ki te mata—whaiapu, ki te mata—tuhua, me te mira tuatini, te kukumoe—toka, te ngaeo (T. 152).   Kuku—para, small species of mussel.7.Fear.8.Nightmare. Ka moe koe, a e haere mai ana te wairua o tetahi tangata ki te patu i a koe, he kuku tena.9.Colic.10.A pattern of carving kūkuku1.v.t. Tie up, lash up. Kai atu, whakairi atu, kūkuku rawa, roiroi rawa ki te pataka tapu a Raukatauri (M. 291).2.n. Atrina zelandica, fan mussel. = kūkukuroa3. Cyathodes juniperina, a shrub.4.a. Shrivelled up, as by fire.'
see kuai'
see kuku'
kūkukuroa see kuku'
see kuku'
see kume Kukumoetoka see kuku'
a. Covetous, parsimonious.'
see kumu'
see kune'
see kupa'
n. A river bed. (Tahu).'
see kuku'
see kupi'

n. Scirpus maritimus, a swamp plant. Te take o te kukuraho, pena tonu te mangaro i te taro.—Ka kumea ki uta, ka patua, ka mate, ka rere tetahi o nga raho ki roto ki te wai, ko te kukuraho tena. = ririwaka'
n. A kind of shark'
n. Pluvialis obscurs, dotterel.'
n. Bowdleria punctata, fern—bird. Ka haere ki te hi ika, ka tangi mai te kukurutoki, “Kore ti! Kore ti!” he puhore, kaore e whiwhi. see mātā (iii)'
n. A sea bird. (Tahu.)'
see kuta'
see kuti'
see kūwai'

1.v.t. Desire, long for. Used only of an invalid''s fancy for certain foods. Kua kumama ake te tupapaku ki tetahi kai mana, katahi ka tae mai te wairua ora ki roto ki a ia see kumanga2.n. An appetising way of cooking kaeo, etc., by placing them in mussel shells upon hot embers. kumamatangan. Relish, something to tempt the appetite. K a kohia nga tauhere ma te tupapaku hai kumamatanga ake.'
v.t. Tend carefully, foster. He pott na Uekahia, ma Rongotakutama e kumanu (P.).'
see  kumama, komanga  He tangata kumanga iti (A sparing eater).   Kumangakai, food placed for consumption by the spirit of a dead relative.'
n. Ipomoea batatas, sweet potato. The names of a large number of varieties are recorded. Ka koa nga tama a Paoa ki a ia, no te mea ka tae atu hei karakia i a raua mara kumara (T. 199).'
n. 1.Pomaderris elliptca, a shrub.2.Quintinia serrata, a tree.3. Olearia colensoi, a shrub.4.Angelica rosaefolia, a herb.'
n. Olearia furfuraeea, a shrub.'
n. Olearia colensoi, a shrub.'
n. A fish.'
komau'

kukume1.v.t. Pull, drag. Katahi a Whakatau ka nanao ki te pito o tana taura … katahi ka kumea (T. 62).2.Pull out, stretch. Takahia ana e Maui te iwi—tuaroa, kumea ana te whiore, haere ana he kuri (T. 26). Ka kumea e Maui te moana kia roa (T. 20).3.Drag or pull away. Katahi ia ka rere atu ki te kukume mai i nga puru o te pihanga (T. 13). Kume rua, perplexing, distracting. Ka taka ko roto nei me he au kume rua (M.M. 155).  4.n. Asthma, asthmatic person. see kumi Kukumen. A star. kumekume1.v.t. Draw, attract, pull, drag. He karakia e kumekume ana i nga hau o te rangi (T. 92). Katahi ka kumekumea iho (T. 154). Kumekume a Ruaumoko, earthquake.  2.n. The holding struts on the up—river side of a lamprey weir (Whang.).'
v.i. Mutter see hameme'
kumara'
n. Wooden bowl or trough. Taupoki ana mai taku kumete i runga i te tumuaki a Tako (M. 282).'
n. 1.A measure of ten fathoms. Ko te roa o te whare kotahi kumi ma ono (Pi. 135, 5).2.A huge fabulous reptile.'

n. 1.Beard. Used in the singular or plural. E kore e oraora nga kumikumi o Haumatangi (P.).2.White throat feathers of the parson bird.3.Byssus of mussels, etc.4.Black whalebone of the right whale.5.Tattoo marks (Shortland says under the eyes).'

1.n. Headland, promontory. Ka kite atu a Tama—te—kapua ki te kumore o Maketu (T. 75).2.v.t. Project. Katahi a Te Arawa ka whakahekea ki te Waha o te Parata, ka kumorea te ihu o te waka ki te korokoro o te Waha o te Parata, ka rima tauare o taua waka ki te wai.'
see komou'
n. Headland see tūmū'

1.n. Anus.2.Posterior, buttocks. Kei runga te kumu o tetahi (T. 116).3.Tail of a bird. I te kumu pitakataka (M. 283).4.v.t. Clench, close. Kumua te ringa. Ko te ringa i kumu (S. 39).5.Carry in the closed hand. Kumutia mai ouou tahi ki roto i te ringaringa.6.Hold the breath. Kumua tou manawa.7.Fear, shrink from.8.v.i. Be closed, as the mouth; be clenched, as the hand. Kia kumu tou ringa kei ngahoro au kumara.9.a. Close, stingy. whakakumu1.a. Timid, reluctant. E whakakumu ana toku ngakau e kore ahau e haere ma te waka.2.Reticent, secretive Whakakumu tonu ia, kihai i whakina mai.3.n. A red—skinned variety of kumara.4.A creeping plant. kukumuv.t. Bring together, close up. as the edges of a bag. kumukumu1.n. Chelidonichthys kumu, gurnard; a fish.2.A lizard. Te kumukumu, te mokoparae (W. ii, 72).3.Doubt, uncertainty.4.v.i. Grunt.'
v.t. Dig.'

v.i. 1.Talk unintelligibly, talk gibberish. E kunanu noa iho ana te waha. Moe kunanu talk unintelligibly in one''s sleep, which is considered an aitua, and unlucky.2.Keep harping stupidly on a subject see nanu'
v.t. Tremble, shiver with cold see wiri'

1.a. Cold, pinched with cold. Tangi haua atu ki te rangi kunawhea (M. 334).2.n. Shivering, ague.3.Indigestion O te tonatona, o te taumate, o te kunawhea (M. 325).4.v.i. Gnaw, work, rack of suppressed annoyance.'

whakakūnawhekev.t. and v.i. 1.Nag, fret. He aha tau e whakakunawheke ?2.Gnaw, work, of suppressed ill—feeling. Ka titiro koe ki tetehi wahine, kaore pea e whai kupu to hoa, engari kai roto tonu i a ia te kino e whakakunawheke ana see wheke'

kukune1.a. Plump, filled out to roundness.2.v.i. Swell as pregnancy advances. Na ka kukune te wahine, katahi ka haere a Ihenga ki te whakangau kiwi mo te turakanga. Ka kukune te hapu o tana wahine (T. 127).3.Spring, grow. I kune mai i Hawaiki, te kune kai, te kune tangata (Ika, 192). I to kunenga mai i tawhiti (M. 89). kukunetangan. Advancing pregnancy. kunekunea. Appearing round. E to, e te ra, kunekune ana ki te rua (S.).'
v.t. Beg. = unene'
a. Dark. Kia kunikuni ka puta te marama.'
a. Wrinkled, puckered see pungenge'
see kuku'
n. A species of mussel.'
n. Arripis trutta, a fish. = kahawai(R.)'
v.t. 1.Grind, rub down. Ka hoatu te tunaeke hai kuoro ki te wai.2.Grate. Ki te kuoro kai ma tatau see oro'
n. Atrina zelandica, fan mussel.'
n. Mildew.'
v.i. 1.Belch, throw up wind from the stomach.2.Gasp. Ka tutu te huka o te waha, a ka kupa te tangata ra ki te wai mona (P. 98).'

1.a. Prostrated, exhausted. Ko Paka kai te taha o te ahi e kupa ana, kua mate.— Ka haere, a kupa noa iho ki te huarahi (i.e., takoto noa iho) see kopa2.v.i. Soar. Tirohia atu Tarakumukumu kai te moana e kupa ana. kukupan. Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae, pigeon. E takoto ana te kai nei a te kukupa (T. 146). = kereru kupakupa1.a. Drooping, flaccid.2.n. A species of eel.3.An insect; wood—louse.'
n. A hard woody fungus on trunks of trees.'
n. Clupea antipoda, sprat.'
a. Dark in colour, as potatoes spoiled by the heat of the sun.'

1.v.i. Lie flat.2.Stoop. I kupapa mai te tahae, koia hoki te kitea ai.3.Go stealthily.4.Remain quiet, become passive Kei oho koutou, kupapa marie (K.M. ''60,19,14). Na te mea ka whiua, katahi ano ka kupapa, ka hoki mai ki konei noho ai (W.M. viii, 152).5.Be neutral in a quarrel. Nau te whakaaro ki te kupapa, a e pai ana (K.M. ''62, 2, 11).   The term was applied to the friendly Maoris in the war of the sixties.6.ad. At a low level. Ko au ia e rere kupapa ana i te mata o te whenua (Fly near the ground) (K.M. ''63, 2, 22).7.n. Tetrapathaea tetrandra, climbing plant.8.A pattern of ornamental lattice—work for interior of a house. kūpapapapa1.a. Low.2.n. Sulphur.'
1.a. Completely blackened. Applied to a person fully tattooed.2.n. A cape made wholly of black dogskins.3.Size, extent.'
kūparuparua. Dirty.'
n. Zeus faber, John Dory; a fish.'
n. Net. Kihai i roa kua oti nga kupenga ra te tatai (T. 142). E kume ana te iwi nei i tana kupenga (T. 178). Kupenga a Tara—maikuku, clouds in strata.  '
1.v.i. Flow swiftly see pere (ii)2.a. Fat.3.n. In the expression kupere waka, sack of a village, with destruction of all the inhabiants.'
kukupia. Shrivelled up.'
a. Sticky, clammy see pia'

1.n. Anything said. Kahore he kupu a te mohoao (The man from the wood has not anything to say) (T. 139.) Ka puaki atu te kupu a te wahine nei (The woman said) (T. 187).2.Saying. Ko te kupu tenei mona, “Kai hanu, kai hanu,” etc. (P. 105).3.Message. Kahore he kupu a nga tuakana, a nana anake te kupu i rere mai ai ki a au, “E kore au e tukua mai” (T. 199).4.Word, Ngangahu ke ana te whakahuatanga mai o nga kupu (T. 42) Ka rite nga kupu o tana waiata (Pi. 133, 11).5.Talk. Ka ekengia e te kupu (Be the subject of talk, generally of adverse criticism). eke.6.v.i. Speak. Te kupu te tahae, te aha (W. v, 110). kupukupuv.i. and v.t. Speak frequently, or at length, or emphatically. E kupukupu ana tenei tangata kia patua te manubiri,— Nga iwi kupukupu, nana te ki, nana te kohuru (M. 47). Mo nga whenua e kupukupua nei e te ngutu (K.M. ''63, 3, 1). Na ka kupu kupuria mai e te hunga i te pa (K.M. ''60, 5, 3). '

1.a. Red, glowing. He kahu kura te kakahu (T. 101) see ura2.Ornamented with feathers. Mahue ake te maipi kura a Rua (T. 77). Me te taiaha—a—kura ki te ringa (J. xx, 20).3.Precious. To whenua kura ka mahue (M. 40).4.v.t. Redden, paint red. Te kuranga o Hunakiko(T. 113).5.n. Red feathers, used as a chaplet, ear ornament, or other adornment. Kua ara te kura o tona taiaha ki runga (J. xx, 23). He kura, ara he pohoi whero kei nga taringa (J. iii, 100).   Hutia te kura, i o taringa (M 295). Nui ake te kura o tenei kainga i te kura o Hawaiki (T. 74).   So kakahu—kura (q.v.), which was also spoken of as kura see kurawhero6.Red ochre. = takou7.Ataiahaadorned with red feathers. Called also taiaha a kura.8.Treasure, valued possession, darling. He kura kainga e hokia; he kura tangata e kore e hokia (P.). Ka mea raua kua whiti mai te kura, ara te kao kumara o Hawaiki ki Aotearoa. Taku kura tangi whakaingoingo (M. 330).9.A red variety of kumara, reserved for the tohunga and ariki.10.Chief, man of prowess. Nana te kahui kura, nga taonga whakamanamana (M. 10). He toa kura, he toa pahekeheke (P.).11.Knowledge of karakia and other valuable lore. = wananga. Kura huna, knowledge of a specially important nature. The whare kura was a building devoted to instruction in this knowledge.12.Young of kuaka (Limosa lapponica baueri, eastern bar—tailed godwit).13.A variety of kaka (Nestor meridionatis). He kaka kura.14.Ceremonial restriction. = tapuKua whati hoki te kura, ara te kura o te tapu. Horahia te kura, an expression for making peace. Me tango ki te kura mahora, na katahi ka horahia, na ka mau te rongo (T. 166.) Houhia ki te rongo, horahia ki te kura (M. 16).  15.The expression kura-takai-puni, simultaneous movement of a body of warriors, is treated as a separate word see kura—takahi—puni kurahaupon. Lunar rainbow. kurakuran. Excrement. He tangata kai kurakura. (An expression of contempt.) kurateaa. Pale red, reddish. Tirohia te marama, he marama kotea ranei, he kurahaupo ranei, he kuratea ranei ?'
v.t. Remove lice from the hair. = hakura'
1.v.i. Project, be prominent. Ko te kuraetanga o tona ihu (T. 75).2.n. Headland. A u atu nga kurae ki Te Kawakawa (M. 46). kuraenga = kurae 2'
kuraihanan. Eliotris radiata, a fish. I pahure ki reira te kuraituhi te kuraihana (J. iii, 106).'
v.i. Spread out, extend. Applied to a war party see kura 10, hora'
see kurahina'
n. A fish (J. iii, 106)'
n. Annoyance. whakakūrakurakuv.t. Annoy, disturb. Kati ra to whakakurakuraku.'
a. Having a roof of medium pitch; less steep than haeoratu, but more so than kurapapa or pora.'
n. Dicksonia fibrosa, a tree—fern.'
1.a. Idling, trifling, having no object. Te koiwi kurapa ! (The vagabond !)2.Unsuccessful in fishing or acquiring property, etc see korapa3.v.i. Spread out.'
n. Treasure lit upon accidentally. He kurapae na Mahina (P.). = paekura'
a. Flat—roofed see kuramatanui'
n. A variety of kumara.'
a. Wet, sloppy. Kurarirari ana te huarahi nei i te paru (The road is quite full of slush and mud) see rari'
a. 1.Perplexed, bothered. Hoki rawa mai, ka kuraruraru, ka pohehe (M. 410).2.Disputed, subject to contention. E ki ana ia i mua kaore ia e pai ki te whenua kuraruraru.'

kura-takai-punin. 1.Omen of success in warfare. Ka karanga ki nga matua ra, “He kura-takai-puni, e kore e pakaru i a ia” (J. xx, 22). Korero i ou tohu, te kura-takai-puni, te toka-tu-moana (M. 29). E kore ranei koutou e pai kia kawhakina te kura-takai-puni ki te whare, takai ai, kei makune, kei motumotuhia e te tahae (from a letter by Ringori Te Ao urging Paora Te Amohau to join the King movement). Note: A prompt simultaneous movement of men under arras is regarded as such an omen.I te hani-kura, i te kawau-ruku-roa, i te kawau-maro, i te kura-takahi-puni (S.).2.A taiaha with the awe bound round with aute.'
n. A tree; said to have been highly prized tree in Hawaiki, Ahakoa nga kura katoa, kotahi nei ano te kura, ko te kuratawhiti. Ko taua mea, ko te kuratawhiti, he rakau (J. ii, 123).'
n. Ambuscade.'
n. Tattooing on the forearm. He tohu ano i te ringa, he whakairo, he kurawaka te ingoa o taua whakairo ringaringa (W. iv, 48).'
a. A pattern of ornamental lattice—work for the interior of a house.'
n. A children''s game (Tr. xxxiv, 53).'
n. A red garment. Ki te kakahu, kurawhero, puahi, kaitaka (T. 95).'
v.i. Cry like a seagull. Kure haere ana, i, karoro tipi one (S.).'

1.n. A species of earthworm. Ka waiho nga kai mana, te kurekure, te whangaio-tama, te kaka, te taiari, te moki, te kuku.2.v.t. Blow, of flies. Ko nga iwi o te ao ki te pao, ki te kai, ko nga ngaro o te ao ki te kurekure.3.a. Pleased, glad. Kurekure noa ana taua ki ta taua taniwha; he koa te tino tikanga o tena kupu. (Said of a large pig killed by hunters.)'
n. Fold, wrinkle. kūreherehe1.a. Wrinkled, soft, flabby.2.n. A species of winkle, mollusc.'
1.a. Indistinctly seen, dim. Kurehu ake i a au e haere ana i kona see rehu.2.v.i. Doze.'
n. Point of the nose. Te kurae ra, ko te kureitanga o toku ihu (J. ii, 223) see kurae'

1.n. Some form of tapu, violation of which was supposed to lead to withering of crops.2.v.i. Quiver. whakakurepe1.a. Accompanied with quivering of the hands and similar gestures. Katahi ano ka puta a Nuku ki waho, ka tangi whakakurepe.2.Crying as a child.3.v.t. Extend. Ka whakakurepetia tetahi wahi o te pa hei tunga mo te paepae. (Part of the palisade was extended to enclose a site for the latrine.) kureperepev.i. Quiver. Kureperepe moana or kureperepe-a-tai, jellyfish.'
a. Uneven, out of rank. = tireureu'
n. A species of mussel. = purewha'

n. 1.Dog. Ka rongo te kuri ra i te haunga whenua (T. 120).   Kuri ruarangi and kuri mohorangi, varieties of the ancient Maori dog.2.Any quadruped. kurikuri1.a. Fusty, evil—smelling. Kua kurikurikia a ro o te whare (W. ii, 33).2.n. Aciphylla squarrosa, spaniard, speargrass.3.A beetle.4.intensive adverb applied to pouri see kerekere'
n. A cape covered with the long hair of dogs.Kia pehia mai te kuriawarua mo te makariri, e totope nei te hukarere (M. 88) see kahu waero'
n. Dicksonia fibrosa, a tree—fern.'
n. A design in carving.'

1.v.t. Strike with the fist, thump. E kuru ana i te raupo.2.Pound.3.Pelt. Ka tango katoa, te iti, te rahi, ki te kohatu hei kuru i a ia (T. 16).4.Throw.5.n. Blow with the fist.6.Mallet, pestle.7.Fragment, piece broken off; hence, probably:8.An ornament of greenstone. I heitiki etahi, i te kuru pounamu etahi; ko te ingoa o taua kuru ko Kaukaumatua (T. 68). He kuku tongarerewa (M. 134).9.The tongue on the end of the body of a canoe, which is embraced by the paihau, or sides of the haumi.10.Breadfruit, the fruit and tree; now obsolete, occurring only in a few ancient songs. Ko te kuru whakamarumaru o te whare o Uenuku (J. xix, 95). Ko te tapuae o Tama-te-kapua i tikina ai te kuru o Uenuku (S.).  Hua-kuru is the name of a stone (Mng., Sa., Ha., Ta., Rar., ulu, kuru.) whakuruv.t. Pelt. kurukurun. Lump see pokurukuru'

v.t. Weary. Kuru rawa i aku iwi, kohi rawa i aku kiko (M. 308). kurukurua. Weary, weak. Kurukuru ana nga iwi. Tena ko taku nei tangi ka whakawai kurukuru. whakakuruv.t. Weary. Ko te tane tena i ako ai ki aroha, no muri na te rau na, whakakuru kau mai (M. 177). Kuruhenga = kuruwhenga'
n. Buttocks.'
a. Blunt see puhuki'
n. A fish.'

1.n. A charm word, pronounced to divert threatened danger to someone else.2.v.i. Wither, become powerless. Kuruki whakataha te niho o te tupua (S.). Kuruki o atua, kuruki o tapu, kuruki o makutu (M. 409) see kuru (ii)3.a. Violent. Ma wai ra au e karawhiu ? Ma te tuatini rawa i te hau kuruki, i te hau kaha (S. ii, 73) see kuru (i)'
a. Curdled, as milk.'
n. Tattooed man. (R.)'
1.n. Person of no account. Ka hua au ki te tangata nei, ki a Te Hana, he tangata pai; kaore, he kurumetometo.2.a. Of small stature.'
n. Beam, joist, sleeper.'
1.n. A game.2.a. Noisy. To mahi, te kurupakara'
n. A kind of stone used for grinding (Tr. xxiv, 513).'
n. Fringe or plaited hem on the edge of a cloak. He pauku, he mea taniko nga tapa: ko te remu he mea kurupatu ki te huruhuru kuri tonu.'
a. In a compact body. Kaua e wehewehea, otira kia kurupe.'
n. Clod see kerepei'
v.i. Repress the feelings see pena'

kurupine Kurupene Tu, e hine, i to manawa, kurupene Rongo i to manawa (M. 16). Kurupine Tu i te manawa (M. 466). Note: Grey, on the strength of a Maori note on the former passage, says beating the breast, but this does not seem satisfactory.'
a. Of a mossy, spongy consistency. Karakia, mo te hore, kurupo, he kea ranei (M. 43) see kurupopo'
kurupopopoa. Rotten, worm-eaten (of timber). Nga mea kua kurupopo noa atu (W. v. ii).'
n. Tail of a bird see remu'
kurutahin. Weakness, weariness whakakurutahia. Weary. Te ngakau haere whakakurutahi tonu no nui o rangi ra (M. 237) see kuru (ii)'

n. 1.A hard dark-coloured stone used for making weapons. Nga ingoa o aua kohatu, te mea ma he tuapaka, te mea pango he kurutai, te mea whero he maka hua. = onewa, okewa2.A weapon made of this stone. He riri matakitahi, raua ko tetehi tangata, he taiaha ta tetehi, he kurutai ta tetehi.'
kurutaitaia. Salt, brackish see tai, kutaitai'
n. Stone beater.'
kurutetetev.t. Crush, compress. He rau harakeke kurutetete no Panekoki.'
v.t. Exchange.'
a. 1.Stunted see kurutote, hurutete'
v.i. Swoop.'
a. Stunted.'
a. Stunted see kurutete'
n. Tail of a bird, tail feathers see kururemu'
n. A variety of kumara.'
kuruwhengun. Spatula rhynchotis variegata, shoveller; a bird. see kahoho'

kurahengav.i. Make a snuffling sound with the nose. He aha tenei e kuruwhengu nei ?In the following example, expressing disapproval: Tukua kia haere, he waka no te tangata, kai kuruhengutia, mate rawa hoki au (S. ii, 82). '
n. Encumbrance, clog, as old and infirm people on a march. Ruia atu te kuta kia ngahoro atu.'

kūkuta, kutakutan. 1.Scirpus lacustris, a rush. Ko te tarutaru ano tetehi ara, no te marohanga e te wahine, he raupo, he toetoe, he kutakuta, he raurekau (M. Ixxvii). = kopungawha2.A woman''s maro made of the same. Ka naomia atu e nga tangata ra te kuta o te wahine ra, o Te Huinga-a-te-ao.'
n. Mussel; Mytilus canaliculus, M. planulatus, and other species. = kuku'
a. Of a disagreeable taste see kurutai (ii)'
n. Handful, see kuti'
n. Cold see matao'
v.i. Sob, sigh. E hoa, e Neko, tena koe, te noho mai na i tou kainga, te kutare tonu mai na ki a au.'
a. 1.Lazy.2.Confuted. Kua kutekute noa iho ou korero.'
1.v.i. Flow together, rush into one place. Ka kutere mai te iwi ki te matakitaki.2.a. Fluid. kutereterea. Soft, nearly liquid.'
n. An edible plant.'
v.t. Urge on. Kei te kutete a Pita kia awe te mutu te mahi.'
v.t. 1.Squeeze fluid out of anything; applied to milking: Kutete kau (Pi. 3, 7).2.Crush. see tē, korotē'

kukutiv.t.  kutiapass. 1.Draw tightly together, purse up, contract, pinch, nip. Na Hapopo i kuti te ra o te waka, i mate ai te tokomaha (W. 1, 164). He mahi atu ta te tangata, ma Hine-nui-te-po e kukuti mai (T. 30). Ka kitea he tangata, ka wawe te kutia iho e Hine-nui-te-po (M. 329).2.Close the mouth or hand. Aua e kutia ou ngutu. kutin. Nightmare see kuku kutangan. Handful. kukutin. A kind of fishing net. kutikuti1.v.i. Open and shut alternately; so2.Cut with scissors, shear, (mod.)3.n. Scissors. Te kai-kapo mai i te kuti kuti (M. 299).4.Prototroctes oxyrhynchus, grayling. = upokororo'
a. Excessive, severe. Po kutikuti, intense darkness. Perhaps connected with kuti.    Manu te kutikuti, a term used in old karakia, apparently expressive of speed. = manu te hutihuti '
n. Scar from a burn.'

1.a. Stretched at full length. Kutoro noa iho taku takoto ki te taha o te ahi see toro2.v.t. Turn up the ground, grub, root, as a pig. Ariel te kutorotanga a nga poaka nei.3.n. A small fish which buries itself in the sand.4.Pig, from sense 2 above.5.A closely woven fabric worn by fighting men. = pakihora'

n. 1.Louse. Ka rere ki waho nga pokai koko e kai nei i nga kutu o te upoko o Rehua (T. 33).2.Vermin of any kind infesting human beings. Kutu papa, (a) some form of vermin; (b) scale blight. kutukutun. 1.Maggot.2.Vermin of any kind.3.A speckled variety of greenstone.4.An ornament of gannet feathers. Ko te au ra i nohoia e te takupu ko Te Whaiapawa, kia ope noa te kutukutu, kia ope noa te whakairoiro (M. 87).'
n. 1.Delirium, raving, wandering of a sick person.2.Nonsense, meaningless talk. Nga karakia o mua he kutukutu-ahi.3.Incessant grumbling, harping on some subject. ngutungutuahi'

kūahan. 1.Mouth. E hoki oti te huare ki te kuwaha (P.). Also of a bay or river. Kia kite i te wai i kite ai au, kei te anga te kuwaha ki te uru (T. 110).2.Entrance, gateway. Ka piki a Hakawaul na runga i nga kuaha o te pa (T. 177). see waha (i). Kuwai (i) kuwaiwai, kuai, kukuain. A species of shark see pupuwai'
kūwaiwaia. Wet, watery. Katahi te kuwaiwai o te ara nei. kūkūwain. Wet, swampy land.'
a. Wild, of the woods. see wao, taewao'
kuarea. 1.Ignorant. Hongi mohio ana raua, hongi kuare ana te tangata nei (T. 147).2.Low in the social scale.3.Held in no estimation. see ware (i)'
v.i. Long for, yearn, love, desire. Ka kuwata noa te ngakau ki te tangata ka ngaro. kūwatawatan. Light seen through chinks.'
n. Scirpus lacustris, a large rush. = kutā'
a. Scattered, disorganised. Taria e hoki mai ki a matou ra, ko te pukai pani e kuwawa noa nei see wawa'
n. Porzana tabuensis plumbea, spotless crake; a bird. = puweto'
kūhān. 1.Thigh. Tuwhera tonu nga kuwha see huwha2.Connection by marriage.3.Main limb of a large tree.'
n. Notopaphia clegans, a bivalve mollusc.'

kuharun. 1.A grub formerly eaten by Maoris; also a large earthworm, Rhododrilus edulis.2.Gari stangeri and Tellina glabrella, bivalve molluscs. kūwharuwharu1.a. Large see puwharuwharu2.n. A species of eel.'
a. Puckered, wrinkled.'
consonant Pronounced as in English. '

a. 1.White. Ko tana maro ano te mea e ma tonu i tona uma na (T. 15). Ngaru ka ma mai te ripa ki Tokarahi (Waves with which the shore is white) (M. 234).2.Pale, faded. Kua ma tona tuhi mareikura (Pi. 126, 2).3.Clean. Oia te mata o Ruanuku ki te wai kia ma (M. 393).4.Freed fromtapu. Ka ma taku hau tu, ka ma taku hau korero (K.) see mama whakamā1.v.t. Whiten.2.n. Shame, abasement. Tenei te whakama kei runga kei taku rae (M. 140). Ka nui rawa te whakama o Paoa (T. 187).3.a. Shy, ashamed. E takoto whakama ake ana i raro i nga tauwharenga kowhatu (T. 133).'

particle Used after names of persons, the pronouns wai and mea, and terms of address, to indicate the inclusion of others whom it is not necessary to specify. In the latter cases the effect is often merely to form a plural. Kua tae a Horowhenua ma (T. 202). E ko ma, hoki mai (T. 170). Ko wai ma nga rangatira? (J. iii, 98). '
