v.t. 1.Perform certain rites over a woman at or after childbirth. I reira ka kawea kia waituhitia te wahine ra (T. 79). I te ata tenei waituhi (M. 353).2.Perform rites over a child at the cutting of the navel-string. Ka tikina te kai nui, ka patua mo te waituhitanga o tana tamaiti.'

n. 1.A pool of water collected in a hollow of a tree or rock around which bird snares were set. He waituhi te herenga o Tane. Waka waituhi, a vessel set to hold water for the same purpose.2.Freshet, first signs of flood water in a stream. Me he waituhi kei aku kamo (S. ii, 19).'
a. Red. whakawaituhiv.i. Redden, become red. E whakawaituhi ana te rangi.'
a. Dark in colour. Kiri waitutu, dark-skinned. Kiri where, ta ratou kupu tuturu mo tera kiri waitutu (J. ii, 61).'
n. A very transparent variety of greenstone.'

n. 1.Milk.No te mahuetanga o te waiu, katahi ena kai ka kainga e koutou (T. 14) see wai (ii), ū (ii).  Waiū-o-Kahukura, Euphorbia glauca; a plant.  Waiū-atua, Rhabdothamnus solandri, Euphorbia glauca, and Gaultheria oppositifolia; plants.  Noke waiū, a species of earthworm. 2.Relative. Katahi ka whakataka a Ngati Rangiwehi e ia, e Te Moemiti, ka tangi ki tona waiu (J. ii, 229). whakawaiūv.t. Promote good feeling. But that does not appear to suit the following example. Katahi te tangata ka haere ki te kimi manu hei whakawaiu mo tana tamaiti.'
n. Bed or division in a kumara field.'
n. Sleet. Ka maka te hukarere, a ka mutu te huka nui, kai muri ano te waiwaha o taua hukarere, ara ko te mea iti i muri. He ua tona hangaitanga, he ua no muri i te huka.'
see wai (ii+iii)'
a. Beautiful.'
n. Ornament of kotuku (heron) feathers. Ka whati, e tama, to piki kotuku, i, ou piki waiwhara, i, a matua (W.M. ix, 13) see wharawhara (i)'
n. A small crab, used as bait for shark.'
n. A place where certain rites were performed, and apparently the rites performed there ‖ Wai. 23, 24.'

n. 1.Something used in occult rites. Tenei te waiwhero te paheke i raro ra, hei whakamatara mo te hunga makutu (M. 41). Te ritorito, te waiwhero (M. 281). He kore waiwhero kia utuhia, hei wai kana hoeroa ma Rautao (M. 185).2.Menstruation.'

n. 1.Canoe in general, different forms being distinguished by epithets or distinct names. Ka oti nga waka ra te waihanga, ka toia ki waho manu ai (T. 70).   Te Waka o Tamarereti, the tail of the constellation Scorpio. Te waka o Mairerangi, some part of the same constellation.2.Any long narrow receptacle, as trough for water, box for feathers, etc. Ka mate tenei tangata, ka whaongia ki te waka raupo.3.Medium of an atua. Whakaeke kau ana a Hakawau ki te pa o te waka o aua atua, ka kitea mai e haere atu ana te waka o enei atua (T. 177).4.Crew of a canoe. E rotua and e Rua te waka ra kia moe tonu (T. 76).5.Tribe. E penei te uaua i te uaua o tenei waka, i te uaua o tera waka (M. 360).6.Flight, flock, of birds. He waka kuaka. —Me he eaka tieke e waua mai nei e te ruru (S.). wakawakan. 1.Ridge and furrow, row, bed in a plantation. E rua nga wakawaka o te mara nei ka oti see rauwaka2.Share, division.3.A bird. Rhipidura fuliginosa, fantail. E whaia ana koe ki te horetiti, ki te horetata, ki te wakawaka tihau ai i te waru (S.). tiwakawaka, piwakawaka.'
n. Distant home. Kua puwhenuatia tenei noho a matou, kua whakakomau te manawa hotu ki te wakainga, i te kore e arowa te ara moana e hoki ai see wā (i), kā (i)'
n. Centipede.'
a. Having a distaste for food see waha-kawa'
v.i. Hurry, hasten. Wakewake mai ra, e ta ma, haere mai ra, e ta ma.'
n. Appetite, gratified sensation of the palate. E, i, rere rawa te wakea i te waha.—Kahore e rere te wakea. (Said of unappetising food.)'
wakuwakuv.t. Rub, scrape, abrade.'

1.v.i. Bud, shoot. Ehara i te ti e wana ake (P. 3).2.n. Young shoot, seedling.3.Stake or paling of a fence.4.Division of a heap of food at a hakari. Kotahi wana i a matou.5.Ray of the sun, etc.6.a. Well grown; so.7.Fine, conspicuous. He wana (It looks well). Kaore e wana te titiro atu i runga i te kakano kotahi, e rua ranei, tena ki te toru, ka nui te wana. wananga1.n. Threatening, defiant words and behaviour. No ena toa, no ena korero, no ena wananga, no ena kaitaua (T. 88). Tukua te wananga (M. 318).2.v.i. Act in a threatening, blustering manner. Te tupua i nguture, te tupua i wananga (M. 210). He mouri ka muha, ka tara, ka korero, ka wananga (W.M. viii, 49).3.v.t. Threaten. I wanangatia a Raumati e Hatupatu. wawana1.a. Fierce. Ka riri Tu, ka nguha Tu, ka wawana Tu (M. 313).2.n. Gooseflesh from cold or fear. Ka wawana ki te kiri o te tangata (S.). wanawana1.n. Spines, bristles. Tu te wanawana, bristle up, become exasperated. Ta koutou he mea kia tu te wanawana o te iwi nei.  2.Fear, thrill. Ka rere te wanawana, ka hemo te whakamataku o te atua (M. 170).3.a. Fearsome, awe-inspiring. I wanawana aku kanohi.—Ka wanawana te korero a tuahangata.4.v.i. Quiver, shiver, trill. whakawanawanav.i. 1.Throw out bristles or rays. Ka whakawanawana te ra.2.Trill. Ka whakawanawana te tangi mai a te manu nei, a te totoroie.'

n. 1.Lore of the tohunga, occult arts. Haere ki to korua tipuna, ki a Timuwhakairia, kia akona korua ki te wananga hei ngaki i to korua mate. Ka hua te mahara, ka hua te wananga (M. 152). Whare wananga, house for instruction in occult lore.  2.Instructor, wise person. Kihai i tae ki nga pukenga, ki nga wananga, ki nga tauira (M. 355). = tohunga3.A small waka used by the tohunga in certain rites.'
1.a. Satisfied.2.n. Satisfaction. He wanea oti tou mo te homaitanga ra?'

1.v.t. Scrape. Kei te wani here te rite mai, e te tau, ka te tarawene noa (M. 233).2.Skim over, graze, tough lightly. Ko te rongo i tuku mai, wani mai i runga o nga maunga (M. 387).3.Comb the hair. Kia kaua a Ruatapu e wania ki te heru o Kahutia-te-rangi (W. iii, 10).4.Defame, speak harshly of. Kaore te turituri te wani mai a te ngutu (M. 278). E wani, e te ngutu, i te tuakaihau (M. 145). Ara ko te tau te wani noa atu ra (M. 202).5.n. Firestick, for obtaining fire by friction; Shortland says only the one held in the hand. waniwani1.a. Gliding, skimming along. Waniwani tahatika te rere o te kaipuke. Used of certain motions in a haka. Rapea koe kei te turanga hakari, kei te kapa waniwani (M. 385).2.Spiteful, malicious. Aua e whakarongo ki taua kupu waniwani.3.v.t. Procure fire by friction, rub or scrape frequently.4.n. A variety of kumara. = huiupoko5.A charm recited over spears before a battle.'

n. Forest. Naku koe i tiki ki te wao nui a Tane. Ka titiro atu ki te wao kahikatea (M. 190). wawaov.t. 1.Part combatants. Waona nga tamariki nei; aua e tukua kia whawhai.2.Distract one''s attention. I wareware au ki tena; na te maha o nga korero i wawao.3.Defend from enemies. Ka haere ia ki te wawao i a tatou; ki te arai atu i tatou hoa-riri.4.Ward off. waongan. Means of defence. Ko te iti hoki o te poho hei waonga mo te hokowhitu i a Tamaroto (M. 48). waowaon. Obscuration. Waowao nunui, heavy clouds obscuring the moon.  '
n. Bushman.'
n. Dense forest. E noho ana ki te waoku, he pukepuke ki tetahi taha, he puke-puke ki tetahi taha.'
n. Ranunculus rivularisand R. macropus; plants. = raoriki'

wawara1.v.i. Make an indistinct sound, murmur, rustle. Whakarongo ki te tai e wara haere (M. 331). E ta uru waho, e wawara mai nei (M. 118).2.v.t. Desire. He wawaratanga no te aroha.3.n. Indistinct sound, rumour. He wawara taua pea tenei ka tata mai (M. 40).4.ad. Indistinctly. E Rehua, kaore ranei koe i rongo wawara o raro nei na? (T. 33). warawara1.v.t. Desire, crave.2.a. Craving, ravenous. E oho ana i te awatea kei te warawara te hiakai.3.n. Uncertainty. Warawara tupua, uncertain traditions. Ko tetahi tenei ko te takiwa i nga warawara tupua, kua pahemo ake nei, e kore e matauria i tenei wahi nga korero me nga mahi o aua warawara tupua (K.M.).   Note: But another meaning seems to be required for the following: Te tau noa ki te whenua, e tuia ana mai he wara-wara tupua, ka huri whenua, e (M. 364).  '
a. 1.False. He hunga warahoe koutou.2.Fastidious as to food.'
1.a. Strange, uncommon. = haraki2.n. Morning song of birds. Takiri mai ra ko te ata i te tonga ka waraki te manu see korihi'

a. 1.Ignorant. He ware koia koe ki a Whakaue e toa mai ? (M. 245).2.Careless, thoughtless, off one''s guard. Piki ware noa a Karihi (Tr. vii, 44). He whakanewhanewha i aku mata, kia ware ai au; ko wai au kia ware? (M. 73).3.Mean, low in social position. Ka titiro a Paoa ki tetehi wahine ahua pai, he tutua, he ware (T. 185).   Ko taua moenga, he moenga rangatira; e kore nga ware e moe i reira. whakawarev.t. Impose upon, beguile. Ko te haramai a Wheta he wahakaware i a Uenuku. wareware1.a. Thoughtless. Mate ware-ware te uri o Kaitoa (P. 66).2.Forgetful. I wareware pea koe ki ta taua korero.3.Forgotten. Ka wareware i a au te ingoa o tenei wahi.4.Of no account, mean, low-born. He umu kai tini, he umu kai wareware (M. 301).5.n. = wharewhare, a fish. Some form of mollusc.Tangi atu au ki te pupu nui o te moana, ki te wareware nui o te moana kia haramai, kia horomai Hina (T. 27). whakawarewarev.t. Deceive, outwit. E Ruru whakawareware i te mura o te ahi (W. ii, 29).'
n. 1.Viscous fluid, spittle, exudation from trees, e.g., ware-kauri.2.Foam, spume. Te wai e komingo haere nei; he ware no te wai, huka tonu atu.'

pass. 1.Be rendered unconscious. Ka warea te whare katoa i te moe (T. 37). No te wareatanga e te moe o te tangata ka haere te wahine nei, ka oma (T. 144).2.Be absorbed, be occupied, have the attention diverted. Tino omanga o te iwi ra ki roto ki te pa, ki nga patu; warea ki reira, e haere marie ana a Te Ponga ma (T. 171). whakawareav.t. Distract one''s attention, hinder. Ka pura ona kanohi, whakawarea ai koa a Tuwhakararo ki te mirimiri i ona kanohi (T. 40).   I whakawarea ahau e te manuhiri, i roa ai. see ware (i)'
n. Seriola grandis (lalandi), king-fish. = haku, makumakua'
n. Seriolella brama, a fish. Kawea ki tai, ki te moana, ki te huti ururoa, ki te huti warehou (M. 285).'

a. Watery (applied to potatoes spoiled by frost). whakawarin. The second rod, above and joined to the whakatakapū, of a rou kakahi. wariwarin. Hemirhamphus intermedius, garfish. = ihe, hangenge, takeke'
n. Burning coals, charcoal.'

n. 1.Deep hole or pit, abyss, owing to natural causes, as decay of trees, etc. Kore kau noa ake kia kitea tetahi waro, kia pera, me te waro o Pekehaua (T. 158).2.fig. Abode of the dead. Kua riro ki te waro.'

Ko au tenei, ko Tutamure; mau ana te waro ki runga o Maungakahia (S.).  wawarov.i. Sound indistinctly. He reo tangata tena e wawaro mai na. wawaro, warowaron. Indistinct sound of voices, murmur. warowaroa. Vigorous, of growth. He wairakau hoki te mea e warowaro ai te tupu.'

num. Eight. Tatau rawa iho e waru ano taro, kua riro e rua (T. 49). E waru atu hoki Paka ? (T. 147).   With the article, the eighth; and, elliptically, the eighth month. He puanga kakaho ka rere i te waru (P. 25).   He wa kore kai te waru, no reira ka whakataukitia ko, “Te waru pokai kete; te wara o kai tahi.” Te ra o te waru, an expression for scarcity, the time before the new crops are ready. He manawa e kore nei e taea e te ra o te waru (M. 231).   E waru pu, an ironical expression: not at all, by no means. Kia mahue te whanake o Paoa? E waru pu te mahue ki raro (T. 193).'

v.t. 1.Scrape, pare. Ka mahara a Manaia kia tuturia he tangata, hei ohu waru mo ana tao (T. 117).2.Shave, cut the hair. He whekiki tamariki me ka waruhia te upoko (M. 321). waruhangan. Act, etc., of scraping. Nga kotakota waruhanga tao e mau ana i a ia (T. 118). waruwaruv.t. Scrape, grate. He tangata kau Takarangi na Manukawehi i here ki te taura hei waruwaru kao (M. 364).'
v.t. Ka moe Takaroa, ka wata kauere te uri o Makawe (S.).  watangan. Object of desire. Iaua kia tae ki te watanga o Waikato (M. 119).'

a. 1.Finely divided, broken up, having many interstices, perforated, full of holes see tuwatawata2.Loosely woven or plaited. He kete wāwata see watawata 2 wawata1.v.t. Desire earnestly, long for. E wawata puku ana tetehi, me tetehi, ki a raua ake (T. 131).2.n. Yearning. He wawata na roto (M. 119).3.a. Daydreaming. E whakatakohe haere ana, e wawata haere ana (T. 170). watawata1.v.t. Yearn. Ka watawata noa i te ahiahitanga o te ra (S.).2.a. Having many interstices, perforated, full of holes see tuwatawata'
a. 1.Unoccupied, clear, free, open. Ehara kua watea te tane mana (T. 32). Kia watea ka haere mai ai ratou ki te tangi (W.M. x, 22).2.Cautious. Kia watea te tango i to Ngapuhi. see ātea'
pron. 1st per. sing.I, me. Ka karanga iho ia, “Ko wau, ko Ruatapu.” = awau, ahau‖ Ta. vau.'
wāwauv.i. 1.Quarrel, wrangle. Oi rawa te waunga (S. ii, 19).2.Make a noise, sound.3.Discuss. Ko nga tino korero i wawau nei tatou.'

wawaua. Foolish, silly. wāuapass. 1.Be the subject of talk, be discussed. Me he ara peka mai, tika tonu i te huanui, e kore ra e waua (M. ci).   Kei waua e te ngutu (S.).2.Be noised abroad. Te rongo o te paki e waua mai nei (M. 278).3.Be scolded, be rated. Me he waka tieke e waua mai nei e te ruru (S.). wauwau1.v.i. Grumble. Kati te ko-muhumuhu, kati te wauwau mai ki a au (S.).2.n. A pointed pole used to loosen the earth for making earthworks, cultivation, etc.'
wawā see wā'
a. Scattered. Ta taua haere, wawa noa atu. E wawa kau ake nei nga kowhatu o Waitara (M. 74) see kuwawa'
see wāhi'
see wana'
see wao'
see wara'
see waro'
see wata'
see wau'

1.ad. Soon, quickly. Kei hoki wawe o koutou waewae (Sh.T. 182).2.Too soon.3.First. E tatari tonu mai ai a Kiki, ko Tamure te kai wawe i taua hangi tapu, kia hohoro ai a Tamure te mate (T. 173).4.v.i. Be quick, be too soon, etc. E hine ma, me tarona kia wawe hoki au te huri ake (W.M. xi, 231). Kei wawe ia te puta ki waho (T. 150).   Ko tera hoki te mea kua wawe ki te awa. wawewawea. Quick. Kai wawewawe atu, e te ra, te haere, kia ahua te po (M. cvii).'
wawerukav.i. Be bent upon, be intent on. Ka taungatia tenei iwi ki te mahi kohuru, ka waweroka ki te kohurū—Patua te kuri nana, kei waweruka tonu tana hoki mai.'
v.i. Squeal, cry. wēwēv.i. Yelp, as a dog.'
n. Water, liquid, We paraoa, whale oil.  '
n. The middle. Me he ua turuki nei te whekoi ana i we moana (M. 40) see turuawēpo'
a. Chipped, broken. Te tangata niho weha, ko Kae (Tr. vii, 52).'

wehewehev.t. 1.Detach, divide. Ko Rangi raua ko Papa e pipiri tonu ana, kaore ano i wehea noatia (T. 1). E hoki korua te wehenga ki tawhiti (M. 333).2.Perform a rite to divert the affections from some object. He kore tohunga mana hei wehe ki te wai, kia hemo ake ai te aroha i a au (M. 38)   ‖ M. Ixxxiii.3.Transpose. Ka wehea te ata me ona whetu, te ahiahi me ona whetu (M. ix). Ka wehea nga whetu o te ahiahi mo te ata, o te ata mo te ahiahi (T. 71). wehea. Deficient in food. In the expression he tau wehe, a year when fruit is scarce on the trees. E rua tau wehe (M. 323).     wehewehev.t. Sort out, arrange. No reira ka wehewehea e ia ona karakia (T. 8).'
v.i. Be enraptured, be transported with delight. Ka wehe te Hauhau i te rekareka. wewehea. Enamoured, love-sick. Toro mai to ringa, kei te wewehe au, he aroha i mau ki te hoa ka riro (S. 38).'

1.a. Divided, leading by different routes, etc. He ara weherua.2.Dividing, separating. E ahu ki te tonga nga puke weherua (M. 203). He tai ka weherua (M. 389).3.In doubt, anxious. Korohi te rere i te weherua (S. 89).4.n. Midnight. Weherua rawa ake ka puta ta ratou inati (J. ii, 225)   The expressions weherua po, ka weherua te po, are also used. Kei te awa, e, te roimata ka tarutua iho i te weherua po ianei (S. 85). Kaore te aroha, e haramai ana i te ahiahi, te weheruatanga no te po te oti atu (S. 80).'

1.v.i. Be afraid. Heoi, ka whati te ope ra i te wehi ano ki nga tuaitara e tutu haere ana mai (T. 150).2.a. Terrible. Heoi te mea i ahua wehi mai (ko nga kanohi) (T. 159). Ka wehi noa ake te matua a Hatupatu (T. 101). whakawehi1.v.t. Terrify. E kore te tane e tata mai i te whakawehi (N.M. i, 14).2.n. Safeguard, protection. He kore no Tukirau kihai ra i waiho hei whakawehi, e, i, mo te hanga i raro nei (M. 38). wehiwehin. 1.Awe, regard. Haere, e te tau, e; o nui, o wehiwehi, i waiho i te ao nei (M. 269).2.Spines, as in the dorsal fin of a fish.'
wain. Water. (R.)'
weiweiaa. Of low degree. He tangata weiweia. weiweia, weweian. Podiceps rufopectus, dabchick (little grebe). = taihoropi, tarati-moho, tokitoki, totoipo, totokipio'
n. Woodhen, Gallirallus australis and G. hectori. Me te weka ka motu i te mahanga (T. 170).   Weka pango, black weka, a South Island variety.'
1.n. Sonchus aspes, indigenous sow-thistle. = taweke2.Tentaculae of octopus, etc.3.Rootlets of plants.4.A small variety of eel. = ūwekeweke5.a. Small, thin, stunted (? of fish only).'
whekiki'
see wheko (ii)v.i. Be extinguished. Kua weko te ahi.'
whekoki'

1.v.t. Catch hold of, hook, tear. Ka wekua tona pake e te rakau, ka motu nga hukahuka, a tupu tonu ake hei rakau nui (T. 80).2.Scrape. Used also of the erosive action of a stream. I te hotoke ka wekua te wahapu o te awa, o Wairarapa, e te waipuke, a ka puare.—Ka haere te tohunga ki te koraha, a ka wekua e ia tetahi wahi whenua i nga taru katou hei tunga niu.3.n. Bush, wood. (R.) whakawekun. A bunch of fern sunk in water for catching crayfish. wekuwekua. Tufted, in tufts. Ko tena rakau he neinei, ko ona manga ka wekuweku noa atu ki waho.'

1.n. Shoot, runner, of a gourd, etc. Tuku marire ki te wene hou nei (Of an upstart) (S.).2.Food. (R.)3.a. Many, numerous (of small things). He wene, he wene, he wene noa atu.—Ka mutu nga wene korero o tenei kainga. whakawenev.t. Make into a noose. wenewene1.n. Lagenaria vulgaris, calabash gourd, and other creeping plants. Muri iho ka hia e ia te wenewene whenua, ka mate (T. 17).2.Sphinx convolvuli, a large moth.3.Scar, scab. Hui ake ki te wenewene i runga (M. 286).4.Orifice of a wound.5.Holes in a native flute.6.Anus.7.Particle, small portion.8.Unimportant, of small account. Hil he kupu tau, e te wenewene? ka mea au he tangata mana e korero.'
1.v.i. Grumble, carp, cavil.2.n. Dislike, envy, hatred. wenewenev.i. Dispute, disagree. see harawene, wenerau'
n. Shoot of convolvulus or other creeper.'
v.t. Grumble at, censure. Te mu mai a te tini, te wenerau a te mano (M. 125) see wene (ii)'
n. A variety of kumara.'
Nana ano te aroa kai ka hoko mai ai, homai ki konei hei wengoto mo Pohoiti, hei patipati, hei poa kiore ki nga kahitea whare pakaru. '

1.a. Burnt. Ka wera i kona a Te Arawa i te ahi (T. 81).2.Heated, hot. Haere rawa atu ki te wai kua wera tonu hoki (T. 24).3.n. Heat. Kua rite tahi tona auetanga ki to Maui auetanga i te wera o te ahi (T. 24).4.v.t. Burn. Ka tahuna te whare ka weraina nga tangata i roto (Tr. vii, 49). whakawera . — Ika whakawera, the most combative fish in the haul of a net. Ko te whakawera no roto i te kupenga (N.M. i, 29). see ika-haehae werawera1.a. Warm.2.n. Warmth. E mate ana ahau i te werawera (T. 66).'
n. Some parasite on human body. E wero werau ana te wahine.'

werewerev.i. Hang, be suspended. E werewere mai ra te kete i runga i te rakau. wereweren. 1.Barnacle. Te toka i piri ai te kuku, i te werewere, i te patangatanga, i ta Tangaroa aitanga.2.Wattles of a bird. He werewere kokako. Werewere kokako is also the name of a lichen.3.Pudenda muliebria. whakawerewerev.t. Suspend.'

1.n. Root, rootlet. Me te weri manuka e nanapi nei ki raro ki te whenua.2.Upper branches of a stream.3.Tentacle, feeler. Nga weri o te wheke.4.Centipede. Ka utaina mai ki taua waka he weri, he whe, he weta, he kekerengu (W. ii, 189).5.v.i. Take root in one''s ears, be heard with attention. Korerotia kia awe te weri.—Kia weria ki roto ki nga taringa. whakaweriv.t. Alarm. Kei motumotu i nga whakaweri o tau (M. 171). weriweria. 1.Disgusting, offensive. He kai weriweri.2.Disgusted, provoked.'

1.v.t. Pierce, spear. Tutaki ana i taua wahine nei e wero manu ana mana (T. 95).2.Throw a spear, dart, etc. Na ka tatu, ka werohia ki a Rupe (T. 33). Katahi ka werohia te ko, ka mate tera toa (T. 60).3.Challenge the enemy by throwing a spear. Kua huri koaro te tangata wero.4.Plant root crops.5.n. Challenge, incitement.6.Spine of a sting-ray.7.A charm to allay melancholy or love Ka te wero ki te kupu mana (M. 157).8.Tattoo marks on the cheek.9.A greenstone ornament with a chisel point. Called also wero kutu.10.Bite, sting, of an insect. Te wero o te kutu o te tahā wai.  wewerov.t. Spear. E wewero patiki ana. werowero1.v.t. Stab frequently. Ka maminga a Manaia i tana hoe, ka werowero ki te wai (T. 120). Kei te werowero i a ia, kei te patu i tona upoko (T. 94).2.v.i. Shoot or be propelled in numbers. Ka werowero te hina o ona makawe. (Said of grey hairs appearing.)3.Shoot out rays, as the sun. Hakina ki waho, ki te uraura o te ra, ki te werowero o te ra (S.).4.n. Stake.'

weweru, weruwerun. Garment.Kua tirohia iho ki nga weweru, he mea tapeka, ka mohio tonu iho no tawhiti tenei tira; me-hemea no konei he hauraro noa iho te kakahu o te weruweru (T. 147). Weruweru is often used with special reference to finely woven flax mats with broad ornamental border.'
v.i. Pout, project the lips.'
v.i. 1.Be extinguished. Kua weroku te ahi.2.Be decomposed. see piroku, roku'
n. A kind of rough cloak.'

n. Hemideina megacephala (tree weta), Pachyrhamna acanthocera (cave weta), and other species; insects. I utaina mai ki taua waka he weri, he weta, he whe, he kekerengu (W. ii, 177). Wētā punga, Deinacrida heteracantha, giant weta. = tokoriro '
n. 1.Dirt, excrement see paraweta, karaweta2.A wisp of grass used to cleanse the anus of a corpse. Ka tae ki te tuaahu, ki Te Koare, ka mahue te weta o te tupapaku ‖ Sh. Myth. 56.'
ad. intensive Used with pouri  Pouri wetangotango te ngakau. '
a. Feeble in growth (applied to plants).'
n. Spatula rhynchotis, shoveller. = kahoho, papaunguungu, pateke, putaitai'

wewete, wetewetev.t. Untie, unravel, release, set free. E wetea ana mai (nga koko) i roto i tou upoko (T. 33). Ka wetekina te hei (T. 180). Wetekia ake kotahi te tikitiki (T. 101). Mau tonu iho ki te taringa o Tama … te taea te wewete, e Tama (T. 77). Wetewete mai ra taku komutu taramea (M. 273).   The form wete is not used in the active. weteweten. A charm for weakening the foe ‖ Wai. 24.'
whakawetiv.t. Threaten. He kupu whakaweti. wetiwetia. Loathsome, disgusting. Ma wai e ao i te wetiweti? (W. i, 84).'
whetito'
n. Amphibola crenata, a univalve shellfish. = karahue, koriakai, takarepo, titiko'
1.v.i. Be extinguished.Ehara kua weto taua ahi (M. xlviii) see wheto2.Be overcome. Hei tetahi parekura ka weto koia te toa parekura.3.a. Sterile, stunted. Ko te mara weto, kaikore ranei (M. lxxix).'
v.i. Weep. He homai aroha kia weto atu au i te ahiahitanga nou, e Reanuku (S.). He tamaiti tangi weto, a cry-baby.'
Tera te puku te naomia ra, tera te weto te karohia e te kiore. '

n. 1.Single hair. Katahi ka naomia ake te weu o tona mahunga, ka panga ki te moana.2.Fibre, rootlet. E te pu nei, e te weu nei (Ika, 83).3.A tuft of hair used in connection with certain rites. Ka tango te tohunga i te weu i whitikiria ki te tira karamu.4.A feather from the bird first caught, which was used in a rite to ensure further success. Ka hopukia te manu tuatahi, ka tunua te weu, ara te huruhuru, ki te ahi, ka karakiatia kia waimarie ai, kia momoho ai ki te hopu i etahi atu.4.fig. Chief see Wēwē, wē (i)'
see weia'
see wero'
see wete'

n. 1.Poa caespitosa, tussock grass. Mau na ko te wi, na, mau na ko te pungapunga o Waikato (M. 171). Wi kura, Danthonia raoulii; a grass.  2.A game.3.Juncus polyanthemos and other species of rushes. wiwi1.Rushes, Juncus polyanthemos and J. maritimus. Akina iho taua pu wiwi nei; ana! me te poko (T. 13).2.A red and yellow stinging fly.3.Used with wāwā to indicate indefinite locality. Kua riro ki wiwi, ki wawa (P. 63). Ngaropoko ki te wiwi, ngaropoko ki te wawa (S.). Grey says that Wiwi and Wawa were two islands occupied by the ancestor of the Maori; but this is open to grave doubt.4.v.i. Flinch. Ka wiwi noa iho te pa katoa i te wehi ki te pu.5.Make a rippling sound.'

n. A dark variety of kumara.2.A variety of flax with a dark-purple edge to the leaf. winiwini, wiwini1.v.i. Shudder. Winiwini ana te kiri i te mataku.2.n. Dread, terror. Ka rere te winiwini, ka rere te wanawana, ka hemo te whakamataku o te atua (M. 170). Winiwini ki uta, winiwini ki tai; taku waewae tipa ki te kura (P. 96).'

v.i. Tremble, shiver. He wiri hoki nona i te maeke (T. 132). whakawiriv.i. Tremble, feel anxious. Tenei te ngakau te whakawiri noa atu nei ki a koe e pokia mai na e te rehu o te pu. wiriwiriv.i. Tremble. Tenei ka noho, wiri-wiri kau ana te tau o taku ate (S.).'

1.v.t. Bore, twist.2.n. Gimlet, auger. (mod.)3.A lock in wrestling. Wiri waewae, a stroke with the taiaha. whakawiri1.v.t. Twist, wring. Katahi te tama ka whakatika; whakawiria iho te tau o te patu ki te ringa (T. 29).2.Ill-treat.3.a. Twisted. He rakau whakawiri. whakawiriwiria. Violent, cruel.'
n. 1.Flock. Used of koko, kaka, kereru, etc.2.Shoal of eels, etc. He wiri matamoe.'

n. 1.One of the fences forming the fortification of a pa, outside the katua, or main fence. To waho, he pekerangi; to roto mai, he wita.2.Small branches of trees or shrubs, used in fencing. Te wita o te kahikatoa, mauria mai, waiho atu te puaka.3.South wind with rain.'
see wi'
see wini'

consonant Represents the voiceless consonant corresponding with w, and is pronounced by emitting the breath sharply between the lips. It is a mistake to assimilate the sound to that of f in English, though this has become fashionable in recent years with some of the younger Maoris. In some words wh and h are interchangeable, as kohatu, kowhatu; mahiti, mawhiti. In a few words there is confusion between wh and w, but this may be due to the fact that in early works printed in Maori no distinction was made between the two, both being printed as w. Wh is never found in Maori followed by o or u. '
num. 1.Four, fourth.2.Elliptically, fourth month. Ka tae ki te wha, ka tima marere i te mara tautane.'
v.i. Be disclosed, get abroad. Ka wha i konei te tahae a Ruatapu.'

n. 1.Leaf; particularly, if not exclusively, applied to one with a sheathing base, as taro, and most frequently to ensi-form leaves, as those of flax, etc. He wha tawhara ki uta, he kiko tamure ki tai (P. 30).   Na ka tataia mai he harakeke, engari kaore i haehaea mai kia ririki, tihore tonu i te wha tonu.2.Flake.3.Feather. Kia tia whakaripa te wha o te huia (S.). whāwhā1.n. Sheathing petiole, as of taro leaf.2.v.t. Take in the hand, feel with the hand. No te whawhatanga atu, na, ngahorohoro noa iho (J, ii, 123). Whawha rawa ake me he ri mangemange (M. 139).3.Lay hold of. Whawharia mai ana e Uenuku, horomia oratia ana taua tamaiti (T. 107).'
whakacausative prefix Words with this prefix are, in general, referred to their root words.'
n. A respectful term of address to a woman. Madam. E whae, haere, tikina nga ika (T. 118). E whae, hoki iho (T. 48). see whaea'
n. Mother, aunt. Ka mau ki te patu ka patai ki te whaea (T. 136).'
n. Mother, aunt.'
n. 1.Dam, mother, of animals.2.Mother of one''s children, wife. Ka mea iho ki te whaereere (T. 136).   Ka mea ia ki tana whaereere. “E whae” (W. iv. 102).'
1.n. Dasyatis brevicaudatus, sting-ray, and Raja nasuta, skate. Te whakangungu nei ki nga tara a whai o Arai-te-uru (P. 90).'

Rhinobatis banksii; a ray. Whai kuku, small brown sting-ray.    Whai repo, Torpedo fairchildi, electric ray.    Whai whai, a species of flat-fish  (Tahu. Whai manu, another variety of ray. ) Te whai a Titipa, the Coalsack, a dark spot near the Southern Cross.  2.Cat''s-cradle; a string game. He whai, na nga kaumatua me nga taitamariki tenei takaro (W. ii, 121).3.v.i. Play at cat''s-cradle. Kei te rehia; e teka ana, e ku ana, e whai ana (W. iii, 7).'

a. 1.Possessing, equipped with. Ka whai ringaringa, ka whai waewae, ka tupu au he tangata (M. 414).2.Becoming, acquiring the shape or character of. Na toku tipuna au i awhi, a whai tangata ana ahau.3.Settled, constantly resident. He tangata whai ahau.'

1.v.t. Follow, pursue. Ka kite koutou i te waka e whai mai ana i muri i a matou (T. 173).2.Look for, go in search of. Kua riro ki uta ki te whai kai (T. 81). Ka haere a Whakatau, ka uru ki roto ki te whai wahie (T. 61).3.Court, woo. He whai ta Tuka i a Te Kahu hei wahine mana.4.Proceed to the next in order. E karakia ana te koroheke ra; kua oti tetehi karakia, e whai ana ki tetehi (T. 201).5.Aim at, design. E whai ana a Paka kia riro te waka i a ia.6.Practise. Ka rere au ki Ngapuhi ra, ki te tama whai riri (M. 360).7.Perform an incantation or rite. Haere mai ki runga ki toku waka ki te whai ake i te kawa o te waka nei (T. 70).8.Lay hold of. Ka whai ia i nga iwi o te hakoro, ka puta ki waho (Tr. vii, 49).9.n. A spell to cure wounds and other injuries.He whai kanohi me ka pohea (M. 281). He whai mo te tangata wera i te ahi kia mahu ai (M. 430). whāingan. 1.Circumstance, etc., of pursuing, etc.2.Enmity, hostility, quarrel. He iti te whainga, he nui te paremata (P. 15).   Kei hea te tangata hei ki mo te whainga?3.Ceremony for removing tapu, etc. I mea ia kia patua he tangata hei whainga mo tona whare. whāwhai1.v.i. Be in haste, be hurried. He whawhai nona kia rokohanga ai nga tangata ki te kainga.2.Exert oneself. Ka whakatika a Tane-mahuta, ka whawhai; kihai rawa i taea e ona ringaringa (T. 4).3.Chide. E whawhai tonu ana te hunga nei ki a ratou ano mo te kino o te haka (T. 64). whawhaiv.i. Fight. Ka tohe tonu te taua ki te whawhai ki nga tangata o roto o taua pa (T. 182). Hoa-whawhai, enemy. Moku anake ano ena hoa-whawhai (Tr. xxviii, 44).   whaiwhaiv.t. Chase, hunt. Kua riro a Te Puni ki te whaiwhai poaka.'
see whaikorero'

whaiwhaiāv.t. Bewitch, injure by spells. Whaia atu ai a Maui ki te kauwae, ki nga taringa, ki te ngutu (W. ii, 79). He toa e whaiatia ko te potiki na Tu-whakairi-hau (M. 387).   Kua whaiwhaiatia toku matua e Maru. whaiwaiān. Witchcraft.'

1.v.i. Be in love with a person.2.n. Sweetheart. Ka moe a Tutanekai i tana whaiaipo, i a Hinemoa (T. 134).3.One betrothed. Otira e whaiaipo ana hoki taua wahine nei ki te tane o Te Uri-o-te-Ati-Hapai (T. 39). see ipo'
n. Daylight, open day. A poetical word, generally coupled with ao-marama. Ka puta koe ki te whaiao, ki te ao-marama (M. 243).'
waiapu'
Te po nui, te po roa, te po matire rau, te po whai ariki (T. 73). '
whaiaroaron. Self, person. Patua iho, he kaka, ki tahaki tera; a ka puehuehu, ma tana whaiaro tera (P. 80). I whanake te hotonga i te tainga wai i taku whaiaroaro (M. 256).'
n. Bed of a river.'
v.t. Express displeasure or astonishment at. Ka whaieretia (a Whiro) e nga tangata (W. ii, 8).'

waihangav.t. 1.Make, build, construct. Ka oti ra nga waka ra te waihanga, ka toia ki waho mau ai (T. 70).2.Do, busy oneself with. Ta te ope whai-hanga, he ngahau; kaore e mohio ka mate ratou (T. 92).3.Manipulate, deal with. Ka kawea te wahine ra ki te wahi tapu karakiatia ai; ka mutu te whaihanga i te wahine ra, katahi ka uia te take i haere mai ai ia.'
see whakaihi (ii)O tapu i whaihia (W.M. viii, 58). see ihi'
see whai (i)'
v.i. Make a formal speech. Koia nei a maua whaiki i reira. Kei te raruraru o tatou whenua koia ahau e whaiki nei ki te toenga o tatou (W.M. viii, 59).'

v.i. Make an oration, speak in a formal way. Whakatika ki te whaikorero. whaiwhaikōrerov.t. Hold a formal discussion involving speeches by several persons. Ka tae ki te marae o te rangatira o taua pa, ka noho, ka whaiwhaikorero (T. 166).   E haere ana matou ki te whaiwhaikorero, kia rongo ai i o ratou tikanga mo te haere.'
v.i. Make a formal speech. Ko Uenuku, kaore pea i whaikupu poroporoaki ki ana tamariki.'
see whai (i)'
whanake'
see inu'
waingengen. A species of shark. Tangi kau ko te mapu, kai ana hoki i te ate whaingenge (S.).'
1.n. Anthus novaeseelandiae, ground lark, pipit. = kataitai, pihoihoi2.a. Very numerous. Generally used to intensify a noun of multitude. He tini whaioio.'
waiparan. Dregs, remains. Ka miti whaiparatia na te tangata (M. 133).'
see whai (i)'
whāiroirov.i. Be dimly seen, be imperfectly understood see wheiro'
whāitaitav.i. Distort one''s features, grin. Te putanga mai ki waho, he whaitaita, he whaterotero (Describing a haka) (W.M. ix, 180).'
v.t. 1.Lead.2.Go to meet. see taki'
n. Support, auxiliary force.'
a. 1.Narrow, compact. Kei whaiti ana te awa hoenga waka (M. 233).2.Crowded together. Kia whaiti mai nga tangata. whakawhāitiv.t. Put into small space, compress. Me whakawhaiti nga rakau.'
n. 1.Thunder. Ka huri te tangi o nga whaitiri ki te taha tonga o Pukeamaru (J. xx, 20) see whatitiri2.Plume of white-heron feathers.'
whaitiripāpā Ka whaitiripa te mahi whakamau ki a au (M. 252). '
waitohuv.t. Distinguish with a mark.'
n. Doorway, front part of a house. = whatitoka'
n. Side, region, space. Kei tera whaitua o te manga. I te hoki putuputu tonu o te tira o tetahi whaitua, o tetahi whaitua (T. 160).'
see whaiā'
v.i. Persevere, be urgent. E whaiwhairoroa nei koutou ki te pana i te iwi nei.'
whakaeav.t. 1.Make an immediate return for anything. Hei whaka nga parareka nei mo nga kai a Ngai Tahupo.2.Reply to. Kahore ano kia whakatia mai taku korero. He patu whaka, a return blow.  '

prep. Towards, in the direction of. Horahia te titiro whaka waho (S.). Kei te whakatu hoki i te hau kia haere mai i te ihu o te waka, kia hoki whaka muri (T. 72). Ka maro a raua aho, maro whaka te ihu ana, maro whaka te kei ana (T. 25).'

causative prefix Probably connected with the previous word. 1.Combined with an intransitive verb, an adjective or participle to form an intransitive verb, it signifies a beginning of, or approach to, the action or condition indicated. Po rua hoki a Tukutuku e whakatata ana ki a Paoa, kihai i tata (T. 199). Na ka whakawhiti a Kupe i te moana o Raukawa, a ka whiti (Then Kupe set about crossing the straits of Raukawa, and crossed over (T. 109).2.Combined with a noun to form an intransitive verb, it signifies the assumption of the character or form expressed by the noun. Kua whakatangata taua kukupa (T. 16).3.As a strict causative it may combine with a verb, adjective, participle, or noun to form a transitive verb. Katahi ano a Rupe ka whakakukupa i a ia (Made himself into a pigeon) (T. 33). Kia nunui te tao, kaua e whakaririkitia (Don''t let them be made small) (T. 118). E Kupe, e, whakahokia mai te waka ki a au (Make the canoe return to me) (T. 109).   Other varieties and shades of meaning will be found under the word to which whaka is prefixed in each case. see whā (iv)'
see kana'
see kao'
see kapa'
v.i. Contort the body and features, as in a haka. Ka turia te haka, ka puta a Tapoto ki mua whakapi ai.—Ka whakapi haere te wero see whākapakapa'
whakatauki see tau (v)'
n. The star Castor or Pollux see ahu, whakaahu'
v.t. 1.Surround with a net, etc.2.Place or draw anything round something. Ka whakautia te kaharoa, ara ka whaka-marotia.'
He tangata ataahua, engari he whakau marie te kanohi; ara, he roa tona maramatanga. '

v.t. 1.Reveal, disclose. Kaore ia i whaki atu i tona ingoa ki a raua (T. 31). E kitea ki te whakinga o aua wheua i nga ra e kitea ai (T. 77). Te taru nei a te toto ka whakina ki waho (M. 237). He maha nga karakia mo te tarukenga, mo tenei mea mo te kanga, kihai i ata whakina mai (T. 89).2.Confess. Whakina, e mate; huna, e mate (P. 95). E pa, kei riri mai koia koe ki a au e ka whaki atu au ki a koe inaianei (T. 129).'
whawhaki, whakiwhakiv.t. Pluck off, tear off, gather fruit, etc. Katahi ano te wahine a Paoa ka hoki mai i te whawhaki pikopiko (T. 186).'
see koe (iii)'
v.t. Eat.'
see kore (i)'
whaāwhākoun. Ixerba brexioides, a tree; particularly when in flower. = tawari whāwhākoun. Eugenia maire, a tree. = maire, tawhake'
hakure'
see kuru (i)'
v.i. Be far away, be distant. Ka whamamao koe ki tawhiti (S. ii, 12). Kawha-kina te korenga kia whamamao atu (M. 11). see mamao, pamamao'
see mutu'

1.v.i. Recoil, spring back, as the spring of a trap see pana2.Kick. Kei mate koe i te whana a te hoiho.3.Revolt, rebel. E whai tonu ana mai hoki tenei mea, te kino, i a tatou; e kore e taea te manawanui, e whana ana te ngakau (T. 82).4.Rush, charge.5.Be thrown out suddenly. Takina atu ra kia whana ai o ringaringa, kia hokai ai o waewae (M. 125).6.v.t. Impel. Kaore te aroha e whana i a au (M. 228).7.n. Spring of a trap, made of a rod stuck in the ground and bent over. E kore e mau he kiore ka umangatia, ka pa i te whana o te tawhiti (P.). Pikopiko tonu te whana o te tawhiti (P.) see 9 below8.Charge, rush. He whana taua nei (M. 52). Whana kai tangata, final charge to rout the foe. Taria e tuku atu te whana kai tangata (M. 112).      Whana tukutahi and whana tuku tangata, sudden attack. Ka haere koe i te whana tuku tangata (S. ii, 82).      Whana kokoti, ambuscade. Kaore koa, e, aku ara puta atu, e paia ana mai e te whana kokoti (S.).    Whana turu, a half-hearted charge. Ka kokiri te matua, na kaore i kaha te kokiri, i oma etehi, ka haere atu etehi; koinei te whana turu.    Makamaka whana, dance a war dance.  9.a. Bent, bowed. He rakau whana see 7 above whakawhana1.v.t. Project, impel. Ko tetahi he kopere, he mea whakawhana ki te rakau, he kiri kuri te aho.2.a. Bent, bending. Ka whakamau, e tama, ki waho Raukawa, ko nga moana ra, e whakawhana noa ra o tupuna i te kakau o te hoe (Where your ancestors were bowed over the stem of the paddle) (M. 205). whanawhanav.t. Bend backwards and forwards.'

v.i. 1.Travel, come, go. Apopo maua whana atu (Pi, 175, 3).2.Be on the point of. Nga rere e tangi kei Te wairere e whana nunumi ana (S. ii, 14). Ka karanga Taiha kia apitutia, kia whana te hingahinga nga tupapapaku (P. 36) see whano whanangan. Party of travellers. Te kai ngaro, he putanga whananga ka kitea (P.). whanatu, whano.'
n. Company, party, people. Ka ara tetahi whana. Perhaps connected with the previous word.'

1.v.i. Move onwards or upwards; so, grow, spring up. Kua whanake te tai (The tide has flowed). E whanake ana te rakau nei. Kei whea ianei nga manu korero? te ata ka whanake (As the dawn approaches) (M. 369). Ka whanake te aroha i te pito ngakau (M. 47) see whana (ii)2.n. Steam. Ka huhu ake te whanake.3. Cordyline australis, palm lily, so-called cabbage-tree. Kei te muru whanake, kei te whiri taura (T. 150).  = tiKa mahi te wahine i te kai ma taua iwi, i te whanake, i te pohue (T. 197).4.A rough cloak made of the leaves of the above plant. Ko te whanake o Paoa, e kore e mahue ki raro (T. 191). whanaketangan. Period of growing up, childhood, youth. Au rawa taku noho i taku whanaketanga (M. 164). whānakenaken. Tattooing in the centre of the forehead. Kia kite iho au o hua whakairo, o whanakenake i patupatua iho, i werohia pea ki te akerautangi (M. 112).'
whēnako1.v.t. Steal. Ko nga atua enei i whenakotia mai e nga wahine ra (T. 84).2.n. Theft. Ka mau tana whanako (T. 95).3.Thief.4.a. Thievish, thieving. Ma te matatuhi e kite i te tangata whanako.'
n. Brimstone. = ngawhariki'

v.i. 1.Go, go away. Nau mai hoki koe ki waenganui nei, kia whanatu hoki au kia whakamatau hoe (T. 111). Ko te ara tonu ia e whanatu ai au, kia urutomokia te whare o Rawhirawhi (M. 32).2.Become. He kai ka whanatu ka momohangatia. see whana (ii)'

1.v.i. Be born. I muri tonu mai tenei o tona whanautanga (T. 19). A, whanau noa ana tamariki, puta ake kotahi tekau (T. 197).2.Be in childbed. Ka rite nga ra e whanau ai te wahine (T. 127).3.n. Offspring, family group. Ka rangona e Te Rata e karakia haere ana mai te whanau a Tane (T. 55).   Used occasionally in tribal designations, as, Te Whanau-a-Apanui.4.Family. (mod.) It is questionable whether the Maori had any real conception of the family as a unit.5.A familiar term of address to a number of people. Engari, e te whanua, kei aroha tatou ki tona auetanga (T. 19). whakawhānauv.i. Come to the birth. Ehara koa pea i te whakawhanau tau e mamae na koe (T. 128). whānauapass. Be produced, be brought forth. Whanaua kia tini, whanaua kia mano. whanaua kia rea (Of fruit of gourd) (M. 388).'

v.i. 1.Go.2.Lean, incline, bend down. Kia whanau tou taiepa. Ka whanau iho te rakau. whanaungan. Relative, blood relation. Ka ki ake ki ana tamariki kia hoki atu ki Maketu ki te whakatau i ana whanaunga (T. 78).'
1.n. Liver.2.a. Choleric, irascible. Ka whanewhane tonu ake te riri a taua tangata ki tona hoariri.'

v.i. 1.Go, proceed. Hei ara mou ka whano ai koe nga wai kirikiri i roto Oao (M. 22).   I haramai au i uta, e whano ana au ki tai (S.).2.Lead, of a road. He ara whano ki te po (M. 318).3.Verge towards, be on the point of. Ka whano, ka wareware koe i a au (M. xcvii). Ka whano rawa, ka mate te maia ra (T. 24).4.Act, behave. Whano-kē, (a) Acting strangely, erratic, extraordinary. (b) Different. Hua noa he ope patu tangata; kaore, he whano-ke (On the contrary, it was something quite different) (T. 158). whanongan. Behaviour, conduct, doing. Mahara tonu ratou ki nga whanonga a to ratou tupuna wahine (T. 165). '
n. Vexation, feeling of annoyance. Ka mate au i te whanowhanoa (T. 133). E totoko tonu ake ana i roto i te ngakau te whanowhanoa (T. 82).'
a. Broad, wide.'
n. The star Vega or Alpha Lyrae. Tera Whanui hikitia i te pae (M. 95).   Ka rere a Whanui, ka timata te hauhake.'
see nuku'

1.n. Bay, bight, nook. Mana pea koe e whakahaereere atu nga whanga e rau o Tauranga (M. 63).2.Stretch of water. Naku rawa i rere te whanga ki Kaiapohia, ki te motoi kahurangi (M. 151).   So, probably, in the names of rivers: Whanganui, Whangaehu, etc ‖ Ta. faa.3.Space, any place to one side. Whakarerea atu te rakau nei ki te whanga.—Ka homai ano he ahi, ka haere ano ia, matara tonu ki te whanga, tinei tonu ia.Ko te aka tarere, e tarere noa na ki te whanga.4.v.i. Wait, lie in wait. Ka whanga te wahine nei ki era tungane ona (T. 45).5.Stride, spread the legs.6.v.t. Measure with the extended arms, or span with the thumb and fingers spread. Whangaa te rakau nei.7.Repeat after another. whanganga1.n. A measure of the length of the extended arms.Kia tekau whanganga te roa o te whare (J. ii, 214).2.v.t. Measure with the arms extended. Tena, whangangatia te rakau nei, e hia pakihiwi. whangawhanga1.a. Extended, spread out. Kia whangawhanga te tu o nga waewae, ara kia tatahi.2.n. A small caterpillar which progresses by looping its body.3.v.i. Be troublesome. He aha tau e whangawhanga nei?'

1.v.t. Feed. Ka puta atu a Rongo-rongo ki waho, ki te whangai i a Taneroroa (T. 108). A, whangaia ana e Maui ki te paru (T. 26).2.Nourish, bring up. Whangaia ta taua tuahine hei tangi i a taua (P. 95). Matua whangai, foster-parent.    Tamaiti whangai, foster-child.  3.Offer as food. Homai te hiku o taku tawatawa, whangaitia mai kia pau (J. xx, 23).   I whangaia atu nga kuku hei kai ma tana manuhiri.4.Propitiate, invoke an atua, by offering or incantation. Katahi a Hakawau ka whangai i ona atua ki nga atua o Puarata, ko etehi o nga atua o Hakawau i whangaia, ko etehi i haere atu i muri. Otiia ko te tikanga o te karakia i haere ai enei atua, he whangai (T. 176).5.Offer ceremonial food to an atua; merely a ceremonial use of sense 3, above; the expression generally being whangai i te hau. Waiho kia tae au ki te kawe atu i te hau o tenei tanga ika, a kia tae atu au ki te tohunga kia whangaia ki te atua (T. 22). Ka whangaia te hau mo ana mahi (T. 17) see hau (v)6.v.i. Increase in size, swell. whāngaingain. Food sent to meet visitors on their way. whangawhāngain. A charm. (T. 154)'
n. Mactra discors, a bivalve mollusc. = kuhakuha'
n. Gobicephala melaena, blackfish. = tukuperu, upokohue'

n. Some species of shellfish. Ka waiho nga kai mana, te kurekure, te whangai-o-tama, te karaka, te taiari, te moki, te kuku. Whakarerea iho te whangai-o-tama; kai Porangahau maka te tairaki (W.M. vi, 49).'
n. A variety of Lagenaria vulgaris, calabash gourd.'
see whanga'
see whangai'
hangehange'
a. Hoarse, inarticulate, having a nasal sound. He reo whango. whawhango, a . Somewhat hoarse.'
see ngongo (i)'
v.t. Take greedily, devour. Mauria mai ki konei kai ai, kei whaotia e te poaka. Kei te whaonga o te maara na Tangaroa (N.M. i, 29).'
1.v.t. Perforate, chisel out. Ka whaoa he puare ki te takere o te waka (W. iii, 20).2.n. Chisel.3.Iron tool, nail. (mod.) whaowhaov.t. Carve wood, etc.'

whawhaov.t. with passive forms, whaona, whaongia, whaoria, whaowhia, whao-whina.1.Put into a bag or other receptacle. Whaowhia mai ra ki te kete putuputu na Raukatauri (M. 153).   Ko nga kuri i patua i whaongia e ia ki roto o te hinaki hei mounu (Pi. 132, 11).2.Fill. Ka whaona te whare e nga tangata, ka mano tini ki roto (T. 61).3.Go into, enter. Katahi ka whawhao ki roto ki tana whare (T. 47). Ka whaowhina ki te whare ra, ki tonu i te tangata (W. iv, 36).   Katahi ka whaoria ki roto ki te ngaruru, ka karakiatia, me te tangi ano.'
v.i. Itch see ngaoko'
see omo'
whaongia, whaoria, whaowhia, whaowhina see whao (ii)'
see piko'
n. Polyprion oxygeneios, groper; a fish. = hapuku'

n. 1.A plant; ? Astelia sp. but possibly applied to any plant with ensiform leaves, such as Astelia, Phormium, Typha, etc see wharanui, wharariki, wharawhara, and the use of raupo in paragraph 4 below2.Sail made in a special way for a war canoe. Mo te waka taua anake te ra whara; i mangungutia.3.Floor mat.4.A pad of raupo leaves lashed over the caulking of the rauawa of a canoe. Kua eke nga oa, kua piri te whara, kua piri te taka (W.M. xiii, 166).   Whara hune, the pappus of raupo, used as caulking in a canoe. Haere koutou ki te tiki whara hune hei purupuru mo nga kowhao. This is quite distinct from the whara of leaves in the previous example, as that passage proceeds to mention the tahuna ( = hune) a little later. wharawharan. 1. Astelia banksii, a plant. Me he wai wharawhara e tuturu i aku kamo (S. 80).2.Long plumes of the white heron, worn by chiefs on state occasions. Ko te mahunga tiaina ki te huia, ki te kotuku, maka te wharawhara (S. 26) see waiwhara3.A loop of flax on the middle of the stick thrown in the niu ceremony.4.A fish, similar to kutoro, but yellow in colour.'

n. 1.Burial cave; perhaps also applied to hollow trees where bones of the dead are placed. Heoi te hirihiri e ngau ki Hauturu, e ngau ki te whara, ki nga puke ahua pohewa (S.).2.Mouth of a pukaea trumpet. Ko te whara o te pukaea he mea whakataratara.'

v.i. 1.Be struck, be hit accidentally. I whara toku waewae i te kamaka. Hoki mai, e pa, i te ara ra uta, ka whara to kiri i te paratai (M. 33).2.Be pressed, be forced. To uru mawhai ka piua e te tai, to kiri rauwhero ka whara kei muri (M. 179).3.Be eaten, of food. He aha te kai e whara i a ia? (A proverbial expression for What will he effect?)4.Receive a portion in the distribution of food. Kaore taua e rato, e whara (J. xx, 22). So, whara kai, take food. Kahore ano te turoro i whara kai.   whakawharav.t. Press, touch. Nau i whakawhara ki tou kiri tapu, a whara ki toku, nui rawa te aroha (M. 340).   Mehemea ka whiti mai ko te tauarai ki nga tumanako, no mua ra hoki te whakawharanga nei (S.).'
whārarahia. Broad, wide. Haere, ka wharahi te awa ki Hokianga (S. 49).'
Whānuin. The star Vega or Alpha Lyrae. Wharahi tauriparipa o te rangi.'
n. Fester, sore.'
see ranu'
n. A variety of Phormium tenax, usually scraped with a shell. Called also taroa. Ko te wharanui, ko te awanga, tona ingoa he taroa.'
a. Broad, spread out. Tena ta te mea i moea ki runga i te takapau wharanui (P. 87).'

1.a. Spread out, spread abroad. Kua wharangi aku rongo kaia i maua e Raha te tihi ki Whakatara (M. 85). Te hinu rangi kia whakaturua ki te ngohi ra e wharangi nei na (M. 310).2.n. Brachyglottis repanda, a shrub.3.Anything spread out flat; so leaf or page of a book.'
whatārangi'
n. Melicope ternata, a tree. Wharangi kura, Olearia macrodonta.  Wharangi-piro, Olearia rani, O. furfuracea, and Melicope ternata. '
v.i. 1.Lean. Me wharara ki te pakitara o te whare.2.Stoop. Ka wharara tona haere.3.Decline, as the setting sun. Ka wharara te ra.'
whārahi'
a. Broad.'
n. A variety of Phormium tenax. = wharanui'
n. 1. Phormium cookianum, an inferior kind of New Zealand flax.2.A coarse floor mat of the same.'

v.i. Travel, particularly by water (Uv., To., etc., folau.) wharaungan. 1.Voyage. Ko te take tenei i huaina ai te wharaunga a Whiro raua ko Tura (W. ii, 8). Ka turia i reira te wharaunga a Ruatapu (W. iii, 29).2.Company of travellers. Ka whanatu taua wharaunga ra, ka tae atu ki te kainga (W. iii, 110).'

n. Temporary shed or booth made of branches of trees; perhaps connected with the previous word. Ka to tenei te papa ki te wharau (W.M. xi, 57).   Sometimes applied to a more permanent structure for a canoe. Ka mahia te wharau hei whare mo taua waka see tawharau'
l.n. The back, the rear. Pioi, e, pioi, e, ko te mata i tua, ko te mata i wharaua, e ta taua rangi (M. 144). Ki te pou mua, ki te pou roto, ki te pou wharaua (M. 213).'
a. Large, extensive. Kia wharaurarahi nga kotinga.'
n. Chalcites lucidus, shining cuckoo. Ka tangi te wharauroa, ko nga karere a Mahuru (P. 44). = nakonako, pipi-wharauroa, whenakonako see wharau (i)'

1.n. House, hut, shed, habitation. Haere atu koe i roto i tenei whare (T. 10). He whare hau, a bank of clouds betokening wind.    Korero a whare, negotiations with a view to peace. Tena pea koe te korero a whare na kia houhia te rongo (S. 118).      Rongo a whare, peace brought about by a woman.    Whare tauā see tauā.   But the expression was also used figuratively for mourning. 2.People in a house. E te whare nei, titiro taua ki te tangata nei (T. 61). Whare ngaro, a line or family which has become extinct.  3.A division of an army. Kia nui te Whare, me te Tarahau, kia mau ai (J. xx, 22).   Takoto ake e toru; ko te matua nui, ara ko te Whare (ib.). Perhaps the same as whare o te riri, a part of the picked braves of the army. Ka tohu ia ki te matua nui, ara ki te whare o te riri (J. xx, 23). E iwi e, ko ahau te whare o te riri (J. xi, 133).4.Upper part of the frame of a dredge for fresh-water crayfish.5.v.i. Overhang, as a wave in breaking. Tena Ruatapu kei te whakakaho i te moana e takoto nei, e; te ihinga nei, e; te wharenga nei, e; te marara nei, e (S. 20). whakawharev.i. Take shelter. Ko tona whakawharenga tenei, i te taha o te toetoe. wharewharea. Overhanging. Tera he ngaru kua kitea e ia e wharewhare haere ana mai. wharewharengan. Overhanging bank.'
n. 1.Lycopodium sp., a plant.2.Agaricus campestris, mushroom. (Tahu.)Wharehenga = warehenga'
n. A variety of calabash gourd (Lagenaria vulgaris).'
n. A shrub.'
n. Dracophyllum urvilleanum, a shrub.'
n. A form of aitua arising from dreaming of a house facing the rear of another house. (J. vii, 125)'

n. The building in which the tohunga imparted esoteric lore to his pupils. Applied sometimes simply to the common meeting house of the kainga. Kei roto kei te wharekura e titi huia ana (M. 431) see kura (i-11)'
n. A building for purposes similar to those of the wharekura, though the terms may not be quite synonymous; generally, a house where sorcery was taught see maire (i)'
a. Hollow. He wharemoa te rakau, ka mahue.—Tu ana he rakau puwhawha, haere ana he rakau wharemoa (P.).'
see whare'
n. 1.A parasitic plant.2. Pimelea prostrata, a plant.'
n. A kind of shark.'
n. A closely built house with three layers of raupo in the walls, such as those generally used for sleeping in. Sometimes the term is applied to the principal house of the kainga.'
n. Storehouse raised upon posts.Te hau marama mate o Te Tamatea, o Tama-i-te-ngaua, e moe iho ra i te wharerangi (M. 26) see arangi'
n. Connection by marriage. Kawea te kakahu mo tou wharetangata.'
n. Cooking shed. Ko etahi o te manuhiri nei, i tata ki te taha o te whareumu (T. 186) see umu'
n. Pittosporum cornifolium, a shrub.'

1.n. Anything spread on the ground or on a floor; floor mat, etc. Used of leaves, etc., on which food is laid in a hangi, or which are used to cover anything.Ka haere a Takarita ki te tiki whariki hei tapatu kumara.2.v.t. Carpet, cover with mats, etc. Ka wharikitia te roro o te whare ki te takapau, hei nohoanga mo te manuhiri (T. 192).3.Lay anything out to cover the ground, etc.; spread out, strew on the ground. Na te tangata to kete kai i wharikitia iho ai (M. 127).4.v.i. Lie flat, lie spread out as a covering. Te ao o te tonga, e whariki atu ra na runga i nga hiwi (S.).5.a. Flat, spread out. He kino te rauawa o te waka nei, he whariki rawa hoki. whārikirikiv.i. Strew about.'
see rite'
see ritua'
see riu (ii)'

whārōrōa. Stretched out, at full length. Ka moe wharoro te tangata i te whata pakapaka (P.). Aua e wharoro ou waewae. Rere wharoro, rush eagerly. A ko te tangata nana te utu nui ke ake, rere wharoro te tangata Maori ki reira.  '

whawharo, wharowharo1.v.t. Scrape. E wharowharo ana ia i te riwai.2.Abuse, scold.3.v.i. Clear the throat, cough, expectorate.4.n. Expectoration. Ki te kai tetahi tangata i te kai, ka tuha tetahi i tona huhare, i tona hupe ranei, i tona wharo ranei, ka makuturia, ka mate (S. 28).5.A small species of jellyfish.'
a. Long-continued. Whāroa noa i au nei te mamae (S. 21) see roa'
1.v.i. Lie in a heap. Hei kona wharona ai nga wahie.2.n. Heap. Wharona awatea, slaughter, pitched battle. Kihai koe i kite i te wharona awatea (M. 42).  '
v.i. Move quickly, stretch oneself in running. Kumea, wharona, kumea, wharona, ina ano koe, e Ha na (T. 96). whāronatangan. Stride. E toru ano wharonatanga kua tae ki te ana (T. 96).'
see whārō'
n. 1.A species of earthworm.2.Mud, quagmire see powharu'

1.a. Concave, depressed.2.n. Valley.3.Footprint. whāwhāruan. 1.Hollow, depression. Whakahekea iho te ngana ki waenganui ki te whawharua (M. 323).2.Mother, female ancestor. Haere mai koe kia moemoe tahi i roto i tou whawharua (T. 11). whāruaruaa. Concave, depressed. Ka whāruarua iho nga awaawa.'

1.n. Elevated stage for storing food and for other purposes. Ka titiro hoki ki te whata o te aruhe (T. 79). E noho ana hoki a Tinirau i runga i te whata, e noho inaina ana i a ia (W. ii, 122). Whata roa, whata puaroa, poles used at the tuaahu in certain rites. Ka whakaturia he pou ki te tuaahu, he whata puaroa tona ingoa. Huihui nga korero ki roto wharekura, ki a Uenuku, tauria ki te whata roa (M. 181).      Te whata roa a Manaia, the stomach. Ko te kai hoki ia e parekareka te kaki, e pangoro ai te whata roa a Manaia (K.M. Dec. ''55, 15).    2.v.t. Elevate, support. E whataa ake ana e te ngako o taua ngarara nei (T. 152).3.Bring into prominence, so publish. Ka whataa e te ngutu ko au anake kei te kai kino atu te aroha (M. 157).4.v.i. Hang, be suspended. E whata mai ra te aho i runga i te rakau.5.Be laid, rest. Kei runga i te kauhua te raho e whata ana.6.Protrude, stand out. whakawhatav.t. Hang up, suspend. Whakawhataia to maro.'
n. Litter. Koe e utaina ki runga te whataamo (T. 108).'

whtatai, whātaitaiv.i. 1.Stretch out the neck. Whatai tonu toku kaki ki nga tauranga ki Ohine-te-maire (S.).2.Gaze intently. Maku koe e kawe ki runga Ruahoata kia hapai au nga mata whatai (S.). Ka piki atu au ki runga Whitireia, te tau-mata o te ra, o te marama, e whataitai ai te uiratanga atu (M. c).   To ratou taumata e whatatai iho ai.'
n. A stick placed against the body of one in extremis to afford a passage by which the spirit might escape.'
see whata'
whārangin. Stage or platform elevated on posts. E iri noa mai ra i runga te whatarangi (M. 112).   (Another version reads wharangi.) Ko te karearea ka whakanohoia ki te kaupapa o te whatarangi.'
see tare'
see whata'
a. Near, contiguous. Kia whatata, e, te taha ra i a Paro (M. 177) see tata'
v.t. Measure. Ka whataua atu te ngohi, me te pakihiwi te roa.'

whētero, whāterotero, whēteroterov.i. 1.Protrude. Ko te arero tenei e whatero i mua ra, i o rangi koroke (M. 72). Kua whetero mai te arero (T. 151). Te putanga mai ki waho, he whaitaita, he whaterotero (Describing a haka) (W.M. ix, 180). Kei runga kei te pitau e wheterotero ana te arero (M. 431).2.Shoot out; used of lightning flashing.'

v.i. 1.Be broken off short; of anything rigid, as a stick. Ka whati te kakau o te toki nei. Ana ! me te mea ka whati te taiaha i roto i nga ringa (J. xx, 21).2.Be bent at an angle.3.Be broken off, be interrupted. Ko te tohi a Te Aotaki i a au, kaore i nanunanu, i whati (J. xx, 22).4.Break of the sea. Ka taka ko roto nei kei te tai whati kino (S. ii, 40). Te tai whati tata ki Otamango (M. 114).  Tai whati, broken water, surf.  5.Turn and go away. Ka whati te tangata whenua ki waho (T. 194).6.Flee, take to flight. I aua tangata nei ano ka hinga, whati kau ana; katahi ka patua (T. 202). Ko te iwi ra, ka whati ki tetehi kainga ke, ka tapu hoki te kainga i a Tawhaki (T. 52).7.Come quickly, run. Whati mai, whati mai, ka eke ki te paepae poto a Hou (P. 96).8.Flow. Kei te whati kino mai te roimata (M. 35).9.Ebb. Ka whati te tai, ka pao te torea (P.). whatingan. Flight. Pango tonu te kohamo i te whatinga (T. 101). I te whatinga o Tangaroa ki te wai no reira ana tangata i totohe ai (T. 5). whawhati1.v.t. Break off anything rigid. Whatiia mai nga topito.2.Bend at an angle, fold.3.Put to flight.4.Deny.5.v.i. Be chapped, be broken. Ka mate au i te whawhati o oku ringaringa. Tai whawhati rua, make a slip in reciting karakia, which was an aitua. (J. vii, 131)6.Sleep doubled up; a bad omen.7.Happen; in the expression whawhati tata, sudden. whatiwhati1.v.t. Break off a number of things, break into pieces, shatter.Ka whaka-tokia te mara, e waru nga kopura, whati-whatiia ana, ka toua (T. 114).He ra whatiwhati ko (A proverbial expression for a day for hard work). 2.Bend, as the legs in running. E mua, ata haere; e muri whatiwhati waewae (P.).3.Collect, assemble. Katahi ka haere te tangata ki te whatiwhati ope mana.4.v.i. Come, come together. Whatiwhati mai nga iwi o ia wahi, o ia wahi.5.Be broken. Ka whatiwhati koa nga parirau o Rupe (P. 46).6.a. I tapu i te aha to uru whatiwhati? (M. 391). 7.n. Taku whatiwhati ki ka riro (M. 125). '
n. 1.Angle, place at which anything is bent, doubled, or broken off see whati2.Bend of the arm, elbow. Kei te whatia-nga te roa. Whatianga raparapa, ankle.  3.Portion doubled over or broken off.'
see tika'
v.t. Gather up a line.'
v.i. Drift, glide. Ao o te ori, e whatino mai ra, e haere ano koe te hiwi ki Aotea ra (M. 47). whātinotinov.i. Stretch out the neck, reach forward.'
n. 1.Thunder. Ka puta te hau, te ua, te uira, te whatitiri (T. 93). Ano me te wheorotanga whatitiri (T. 151) see whaitri2.A fungus see popowhatitiri3.Pomaderris phylicaefolia; a shrub.'
n. Doorway. Ka mau te ringa ki te papa o te whatitoka, ka toia; tuwhera kau ano te whatitoka (T. 193).'
a. Te ao whatongtonga (M. iv). '
see toro (ii)'
v.i. Wrestle.'

n. 1.Stone. Ehara i te tangata, he whatu tongarerewa (M. 329).   Especially the stone swallowed by the pupil (tauira) during his initiation by the tohunga. Ka tangohia te kete o nga whatu whangai i nga tamaroa (W.W. 7) see kowhatu, powhatu2.Stone, kernel, of fruit. Te whatu o Poutini is applied to hinau berries (Tr. xxxv, 101)Te whatu o Poutini, he taonga whakamoe i te whare (M. 329) see whatuturei3.Hailstone. Ua whatu or ua a whatu, hail. Te ua nui, te ua roa, te ua whatu (W.M. viii, 113). Te ua a whatu e homai ki to kiri (M. 430).   4.Pupil of the eye, eye. Nga tirohanga whatu a te iwi kua ngaro (W.M. viii, 112).   Ko te whatu kia kite. ko nga taringa kia rongo (W.M. x, 164).5.Core of a boil or abscess.6.In a canoe, probably the stone used as an anchor. “Nau mai koe ki te whatu nei, kia whanatu au hoki ki te hoe.” Ka whakatika mai a Tuau ki te whatu; ka haere atu a Turi ki te kei, ka mau ki te hoe.7.Victim slain at the dedication of a house or pa, and buried at the base of one of the posts. Ka whaihanga Taraia i tona whare, ka makaia tana potiki hei whatu mo te pou tuarongo o tona whare, o Te Raroakiaki (J. v, 153).'
v.t. Weave garments, baskets, etc. Ka kite ia i te wahine ra e whatu ana i te kakahu (T. 187).   Ka whatu manu taratahi mana.— A, no te otinga o taua hinaki te whatu (Pi. 132, 11).'
n.  Ancestor, first parent see matua'
n. Belly fat of fish. Ka kotia mai nga tātā, nga whatuaro, nga upoko o nga hapuku (J. xx, 17). = whauaro'
v.t. 1.Lace or tie together. E whatui ana a Te Aka i te kupenga see tui2.Fold, double, a garment, etc. = whētui'
whatukuhu'
n. Kidney. Ko nga whatukuhu o Ngatoro nga kohatu o waenga tahora? (T. 83).'

n. 1.Kidney.2.Seat of the affections. Kei mea koe he aroha kirimoko te aroha mou, kao no te whatumanawa tonu (M.M. 9).3.Bowels of the earth. Haere atu, e kui, ki te whatumanawa o roto o te whenua. (From farewell to a corpse.)'
n. A figurative expression for bravery which was conveyed by the tohunga to a warrior in the wai-taua rite before battle. Hiramai te whatumoana (The name of a karakia for such an occasion) (M. 28).'
v.i. Disappear. Toitu he kainga; whatungarongaro he tangata (P.).'
n. Pupil of the eye.'
n. Rupture, hernia. Also applied to scrofulous swellings.'
n. Breastbone.'
1.n. Midwinter.2.a. Excessively fat; applied to some birds which become so in winter. Kua whaturua te kereru, ara kua whai taupa see whatuaro'
n. Red heartwood of totara or matai.'
n. In the expression whatuturei a Rua, a cake made of crushed hinau berries, which was regarded as a great delicacy. Kia whakaoho koe i taku moe, ko te whatuturei a Rua (P. 51).'
see turi'
n. Entelea arborescens, a shrub and Nothopanax arboreum, a tree. whauwhaun. Nothopanax arboreum = houhou; also Hoheria glabrata and Pseudopanax lessonii, trees.'
n. Roe of gurnard (kumukumu). whawhauv.t. Tie. Te rongo te whauwhia kia mau ki te rourou iti a Haere (M. 298) see hou (iii)'
n. Entelea arborescens, a shrub. = houama'
n. Belly fat of fish. = whatuaro'
see unu (ii)'
v.t. Eat voraciously, gulp. He kiko poaka ka homai, whaupatia ake see haupa'
whauwhaupakun. Nothopanax arboreum, a tree.'
a. Ruddy, fierce see matawhāura whāuraurav.i. Bluster, act defiantly, scold.'
houhin. Hoheria populnea, H. glabrata, and Plagianthus betulinus, trees.'
see whā (iii)'
n. The moon on the third night. = Hohoata'
whawhai see whai (iii)'
see whaki'
see whākou'
see whango'
see whao'
n. Exultation. Ko enei kupu, he whawhapu na Patupaiarehe, he koanga na o ratou ngakau ki te ika ma ratou (T. 178).'
see wharo'
see whārua'
see whati'
see whau (ii)'

1.v.i. Come or go round. E whawhe mai ana te paoa.2.v.t. Put round, gird on, encircle. Homai taku tatua kia whawhea (T. 97).3.Disturb, interfere with. Ka paneke ki Hauraki, ki te papa no Rotu, ki te aute te whawhenga (M. 242) see awhe whawhewhawhen. Busybody, meddler. He noho noa iho, ka korero tonu, kaore e nga te manawa; he wahine whawhewhawhe.'

n. 1.Caterpillar.2.Argosarchus horridus and other stick-insects. I utaina mai ki taua waka he weri, he weta, he whe, he kekerengu (W. ii, 172).3.Orthodera ministralis, praying mantis, insect. = ro4. Cyathea smithii, a tree fern.5.Dwarf. whēwhēn. Boil, abscess. Ko te whiti a Poutama, he karakia; ko ona putanga he kea, he whewhe, he patito, he aha.'
see hea (i)'

n. Experience, intimate acquaintance or knowledge. Kite wheako, learn, experience; used in indicating distaste. Kua kore au e haere ki tera kainga, kua kite wheako au i taku taenga atu ki kona (I did not get what I went for). Kua kite wheako au ki te piki ki runga (I have had enough of climbing up there).  '
a. Turning this way and that, undecided. Hei aha i whakawheangaanga ai te korero ? see anga'
n. 1.Prince, chief. (So Grey.) He putanga wheao, he ariki taniwha tena (M. 193).2.Companion, attendant retinue (Uv., Fu., feao.)'
awheto'

v.i. 1.Be long in time. E kore ra e wheau, ka hinakipouri.2.Stay, remain. E whae ma, he aha kei ahau e wheau kau ana? (S. ii, 40). Te whare i a Miru, ko te otinga atu o te wairua, kei wheau ake ki te ao (M. 419). whakawhēauauv.i. Delay, linger. Kei nga kikitanga i runga i a Te Kahu e whakawheauau ana (M. 218). wheawheaun. A form of ritual. Ko te wheawheau he atua, he rau rakau ka heria e te tohunga.'

whewheiv.i. Quarrel see whai (iii) wheingan. 1.Quarrel. Katahi te wheinga o te hanga tamariki nei!2.Enemy.3.Very old person. Used sometimes as a term of respectful address. whakawheiv.t. Set at variance, cause to quarrel. He tangi na Te Piata mo tana wahine, na te tuakana te whakawheitanga. whewheian. Enemy.'
1.a. Thirsty.2.n. Thirst. Mate ana i te wheinu (Hae. 95). Tikina he wai mo toku wheinu.'
whēiroirov.i. 1.Be seen. Arohi noa au i taku mea, te wheiro i a au, te aha.2.Be understood, be apprehended. Kaore i wheiro i a au tana korero. see whairo'
whekawhekan. Garment'
v.i. Be dimly visible. Ka whekite, ka whekaro, te kahui tupua (M. 281) see makaro'
n. Internal organs of the body, entrails. Nga maremare-tai o te moana he whekau no Ruatapu (W. iii, 35).'
whēkaukaun. Sceloglaux albifacies, laughing owl.'

1.v.i. Creak. I rangona ake ki te waha e rarā iho ana, ano he whēke rakau (T. 158).2.v.t. Squeeze, crush. whakawhēkev.i. Crowd one upon another. Ka popo ki te matakitaki, aki atu, aki atu, ka whakawheke ki a ratou.'

n. Squid, octopus. Katahi te wheke ra ka maranga ki runga ki te kai i te waka o Kupe (T. 109).   Different species were distinguished as wheke-ngu, wheke-korako, wheke-rauaruhe. whekewhekea. Rough, scabrous. Ko taua ngarara he mea ahua koma, he mea whekewheke.—Ka whekewheke katoa te kaki mete kanohi. (Describing some disease.) (Ta., Sa., fe''efe''e, elephantiasis.)'
whēkerekerea. Very dark. Turakina, ka hinga ki te po whekerekere (T. 28). Te ao whekere (T. 5) see kere (i)'
n. Dicksonia squarrosa, a tree fern.'
wheki-ponga Dicksonia fibrosasee tuokura, tuakura'

wēkiki1.v.i. Quarrel. He tau na to roa, kei whekiki taua (S. 94).2.v.t. Tease, annoy. Ka whekiki nga tamariki nei i muri i a koe (W.M. ix, 27).   Ka totohe te tamaiti ki te whekiki, a kua kite ia kaore ia e toa.3.Beguile, amuse. He whekiki tamariki, me ka waruhia te upoke (M. 321).'

1.v.t. See dimly, see for the first time. Ka turamarama ra te hinengaro, ka whekite, ka whekaro (M. 283).2.n. Dimness, haze. Hiramai ai te whekite o te rangi, hiramai ai te ngawha o te rangi, pera hoki ra te kapua nui (M. 304).3.a. Dazzled. Kai te mata wheriko, kai te mata whekite, he tuhi, he rapa, he uira (S.).'
v.i. Warble, sing as a bird. Taku manu wheko ata, i (M. 23). Wheko-po, Miro australis, robin. = karuwai, pitoitoi, toutouwai '

weko1.v.i. Become black. Ka wheko te riwai i te ra.2.Go out, be extinguished. Meake wheko te rama.3.n. Gills of a fish. whekowhekoa. Indistinct. Nawaki tonu, e, i te ara whekowheko, runga o Tarawera (M. 129).'
v.i. Move about. Me he ua turuki nei te whekoi ana i we moana (M. 40) see hikoi'
wekoki1.a. Crooked, contorted, wriggling. Ki te titiro ki nga rewa i te ihu o Tutetawha, e whekoki ana me he peke ngarara (M. 57) see koki2.n. Maggot.'
see wheko (i)'
v.i. Be seen, be understood. Ka whekori i a au i konei, kei a Kahutia nga pakeha i taua takiwa.'
n. A distorted figure in native carving.'
a. Dripping, especially with any clammy fluid. whekuwhekua. Wet, splashed with water, etc. U rawa atu ki uta, whekuwheku ana nga tangata me nga kakahu.'
pēna'
n. Dwarf ‖ tauwhena.'

a. Firm, steady. I poua iho ra te pou ki Rarotonga, kia tina, kia whena (M. 229). Tina te manawa, whena te manawa (M. 44). whakawhena1.v.t. Stiffen, make taut. Whakawhena te tuara.2.v.i. Stand firm against assault.'
v.i. Steal. = whanako whēnakonakon. Chalcites lucidus, shining cuckoo. Ko te uri au i te whenakonako, i te koekoea; e riro nei ma te tataihore e whangai (S.). = nakonako, pipiwharauroa, wharauroa'

whēnakonako1.v.i. Brood over, yearn. Kaore te aroha whenakonako no ki te mokai whenua e ngakia mai nei (S.) see manako2.a. Wistful, yearning. Kai te kai whenako te ngakau ki nga mahinga o taku itinga (S. ii, 71).'
v.i. Grunt see nanau whakawhēnanauv.i. Exert oneself, strain. Whakawhenanau ana koe i te hapainga i a au.'
a. Rough, choppy, of the sea.'
pēnei Kahore ia i kitea te ahua whenei me taua tangata. '

wenu, whengu1.v.t. Twist or spin a strand of cord. Kai te whengu i ona whitau, ara kai te miro i ona whitau, ka tau tena kupu ki te io, kauaka ki te aho.2.n. Strand of a cord, warp of a flax garment. Ka oti te takiri ka whenutia hei whenu ena mo te tapoto.'
1.n. Land, country. Katahi ka rere mai ki te kimi whenua mona (T. 120).'

people belonging to any particular place, natives. He tangata ano i reira, ko nga tangata whenua ake ano o tenei motu (T. 23). He tangata korero whenua, a pacificator.  2.Ground. Na takoto ana i raro i te whenua, kua mate (T. 32).3.Placenta, afterbirth. I a raua e piki ana, ka taka te whenua o te tamaiti ki te moana, ka kainga e te mango (T. 34).4.ad. Entirely, altogether. Tipatipa whenua (Altogether false). whakawhenua1.v.i. Set, of heavenly bodies. Tera te marama ka whakawhenua i te pae (M. 309).2.Sink to the bottom. Ki te kore e u, ua whakawhenua ki te kopu hopara a Hinemoana.3.a. Immovable. Whakawhenua kau ana te waka ra.4.Restraining, holding fast. Ka haramai tenei, he punga whakawhenua, te whai nei au te tira o Whakatere (S.).5.n. Main posts which support the rails in the palisading of a pa.'
1.v.i. Slip, fall, or crumble down, as a wall, bank, etc. Ko te oranga i te rakau hinga whenukutanga (M. Ixxxi).2.n. A drooping epiphytic fern.'
henumiv.i. Be out of sight, be eclipsed, be consumed. Kei whenumi toku ingoa. whakawhenumiv.t. Mix up one thing with another.'
a. Quarrelsome, resentful see hungeingei'
whewhengiv.i. Be shrivelled, be withered. Ka whewhengi nga puka i te whitinga o te ra.'
v.i. Break wind. = hemo'
a. Little, diminutive.'
n. Something connected with the process of tattooing.'
whenu'
v.i. Snort. Whengu ana te ihu i te kawenga a te whakatakariri. whenguwhengu1.v.i. Snuffle.2.n. Tattoo marks on the upper lip.'

wheowheo1.v.i. Buzz, hum, tingle. Te ngaro taua maia, e wheo noa ana mai, me ona toko (M. vi).2.Moan, groan. Hoki mai noa ana ki te pukai, wheo ai (M. 10).3.v.t. Cause to tingle. Ka ki te waeroa ki tona taina ki te namu, “Me waiho kia ahiahi ka haere ai taua hei wheowheo taringa, hei hoho taringa … hei aha i ona taringa ka wheotia e au … ka wheo ana taringa i a au.”'
a. Uncooked.'
a. Quaking, shaking see oi whakawheoiv.t. Shake, disturb. Kauaka hoki ra e whakawheoitia, kei rere au i te pari, tau rawa ko tawhiti (S.) ‖ M. 252, which reads whakahiotia.'
a. Diseased, ill. I kite ahau i te poaka, kai ko e wheori ana, ka tā te mate see ori (ii)'

v.i. 1.Make a crashing or jarring noise, rumble, reverberate. Rongo kau atu ana nga kaipatari i te harurutanga o te haerenga mai o te taniwha ra i roto i te rua, ano me te wheorotanga whatitiri (T. 151).2.Be jarred, tingle. Ka wheoro aku taringa.3.n. Rumble. Tangi ana te wheoro ki te tuakiri (M. 52). whēorooron. Bull-roarer, a toy. see oro (ii)'
v.i. 1.Bend, sag under a weight. Ka wheoro te rakau.2.Be slow, be long, delay.'
whēraka see pēraMei whera, e, aku mahara me te ao mauru (M. 157). '

whewherav.t. 1.Spread out, open. Wherahia te pukapuka.—E ka kutia, e ka wherahia (S.).2.Take birds from snare. A word used to avoid wetewete, which would cause an aitua. (J. vii, 132) wherawheraa. Opened, spread out. Wherawherahia ra, e, te kapu o to ringa (M. 129).'
a. Turbid. He waipuke, ina hoki kua wheranu, kua punehu. whakawheranuv.t. Mix see ranu'

v.t. 1.Overcome. Kua wherea te whakaaro e te ngoikore.2.Oppress. Ka wherea au e koe ki te mea taimaha see here (iii) whakawhere, whakawherewherev.t. 1.Induce, prevail upon, propitiate. He hoatu tonu taku i nga mea papai mau, he whakawhere i a koe, kia tahuri mai ai koe ki a au.—Ko te whakaepaepa, he whakawhere ki te atua.— Ka hiahia ahau ki tetahi wahine, ka hoatu e au aku mea papai ki a ia hai whakawherewhere, hai whakahiahia mai.2.Oppress, maltreat. He aha tau e whakawherewhere na i to hoiho?'

v.i. Protrude, stand out. Ka whererei nga kanohi. Whererei te puke i te iwi roa, kia tuahua ake (M. 380).   He kotore whererei, said of a person in a fright.2.Be born. Tenei tamaiti i whererei a tangata (K.).'

1.v.i. Flash, glitter, be resplendent. Wheriko ana te hihi o te ra.2.Flash upon one, come suddenly into mind.3.a. Dazzled. Kai te mata wheriko, kai te mata whekite, he tuhi, he rapa, he uira (S.).4.Dimly seen. He mea i kitea e te kanohi e wheriko ana, kia hangai tonu te titiro, kua kore e kitea.—I wheriko noa ake au e haere ana.5.n. Glimpse, flash. I kite wheriko kau atu nei ahau.'
n. Anus. Potaka whero rua, spinning top pointed at both ends.'

a. Red, reddish-brown, orange. Ano i taia ki te takou, te whero (T. 16). Taute te titoki, whero te rata i te waru (P. 85).   Kua pauru te whero o te karaka. Ringa whero, or simply whero, a chief. Ka mahi te hopu a te ringa whero (P. 39). Ma pango, ma whero ka oti (P. 65).   2.v.i. Turn red. Te wheronga o te karaka (Sh.T. 221).'
v.i. Hoot. Whero ana te ruru.'
v.i. Become faint, decline, weaken. Ka huri whenua, e, ka wheroku au, ka mate (M. 364) see roku'
v.i. Yaw about, stagger. Ka wherori au ki raro ra, wherori ana ki te umu hurori (M. 310) see hurori'
hēruv.t. Wipe the anus after evacuation. Ka kokiritia ake te awe o te taiaha hei wheru i te tou o tana wahine.'

1.a. Inactive, slow. Ko nga mea wheru, ko nga wahine, ko nga tamariki, kei muri.2.Encumbered. I whakawherutia ahau e taku tamaiti i mau ai ahau.3.III at ease, weary, oppressed. Whakatika rawa ake au, wheru ana au i te taimaha o oku whakaaro.4.Neap of the tide.5.v.i. Mope. Tenei hoki au ka wheru ki te whare (S. ii, 46). whakawherūv.t. Encumber. Whakawherutia mai ki ahau te tamaiti tangi ai (Let the child be an encumbrance to me when it cries).'
whārua'
v.t. Shake see rū'
1.v.i. Struggle, writhe, wobble. Ka wheta te puku, ki te haka, ki te takaro, ki te pukana see kowheta2.Move rapidly to avoid a blow, feint, dodge.3.v.t. Arrive at, occupy a place.'
whakawhetaiv.i. Express thanks. A word introduced from Tahiti.'
a. Small. He toki whetau.'
v.i. 1.Wriggle see wheta2.Move quickly to avoid a blow.'

whētētēv.i. 1.Be forced out. Ka whete te pirau o te whewhe ki waho see tē2.Stare wildly. Na reira ka whetete nga whatu, na te mea e noho ana te ope ra i konei.—Kua tu ruruhi te manu kaore e kanae nga kanohi, kaore e whetete. whakawhetēv.t. Force out, squeeze out.'
v.i. Be high. I wheteitei ai ko tawhiti, piki ake ai au ki runga o Whitireia, ki te taumata mai te marama i wheteitei te uiratanga mai (S. 60) see teitei'
1.a. Wrinkled.2.n. Old person of either sex.3.Person of menial position, servant. Tohu ake ai au ko taku wheteke rawa (S.). whēteketekea. Rippling.'
n. Land exhausted by cultivation.'
n. Clathrus cibarium, a fungus.'
whatero'
v.i. Whisper, murmur see kowhete-whete'
a. Rotund, protuberant. Te tangata na, i te puku wheti.'
whētikotikon. Amphibola crenata, a univalve mollusc. = karahue, karahu, koriakai, titiko, wetiwha'
wetiton. Bowdleria punctata, fernbird. Taitaia mai te puke i noho ai te whetito (M. 360).   Ko te wetito he ika piupiu ma te atua (P.). = koroatito, kotata, kukurutoki, mata, matata, matuhi'
whētōtō, whakawhetotov.i. Lag behind, be slow see autō'

a. Small. He tamaiti tangi wheto (A child who cries over trifles) see weto, whito whetowheto1.a. Insignificant, plebeian. Koia koa itata mai ai te ki ki taku matua whetowheto, he kararoraro nge au (M. 192).2.n. A mollusc.'
wetokiv.i. Come, go; possibly implying numbers. He aha te ika e wetoki mai nei?—Ka whetoki te manu ki uta, ka whetoki te manu ki tai (M. 374).'
v.i. Step, pace. Ka haramai, ka papare, me he ua torea e whetoko i te akau (M. 151).   Whetoko ke, whetoko ke! (Pass on!)'
see whetō'

n. Star. Tera te whetu kapokapo ana mai (M. 69). whakawhetū1.a. Wakeful, sleepless. E hau ana taku patu ko Poroku i tuituia i te hinapouri, i whakawhetu ai aku kanohi (M. 185).2.n. The hollow on the top of the poupou of a whare to receive the tongue of the end of the rafter. Called also rua whetu. (J. v, 147)'
v.t. Fold, double, a garment, etc.'
n. Land exhausted by cultivation.'
n. A star which sets in the evening in October and November.'
v.i. 1.Throb, palpitate. Whetuki, whetuki taku manawa ki roto (S.).2.Be shocked. E hine rongo kino, tae ana mai te whetuki ki a au (M. 317).'
a. Dark, lowering. Ko ao potango, ko ao whetuma, ko ao whekere (T. 5).   Koia rangi whetuma (S.) see tuma'
a. Appearing above the horizon. Tirohia atu nei ka wheturangitia Matariki te whetu o te tau (M. 254). Kua wheturangitia te marama (W.M. viii, 110).'
n. Hypnum clandestinum, and other feather mosses. = kohukohu'
n. Bone. Ka koa te iwi ra ki te kai mana, hua noa kaore he wheua i roto (T. 142) see ua (i) whakawheuav.i. Stand firm. whēuauaa. Difficult. whakawhēuauaa. Reluctant. Whakawheuaua ana te haere.'
whauwhin. Hoheria populnea, a tree.'
1.v.t. Bear, support.2.v.i. Be firm.'
Me wheunu koe ki te tama kahu parauri (S.). '
a. Dark; so deep, of water. Kei roto te wheuri o te awa. whēuriurin. Darkness. I tikina ki raro wheuriuri ki a Hine-nui-te-po.'
see whē'
whewheia  see whei'
see whengi'
see whera'

v.i. Can, be able. E whi aku tatari ka whiti te atarau (M. 396). E whi te uta atu te puke o Morek e, hei kawe i a au te whanga ki Titahi (M. 256). He oranga ano e whi te whai atu (M. 249). Me te ao mauru e whi te whakawhiro kia whiti ki te tongaparaki (M. 157) see whiwhi'
hia Tokowhia aku tama i horomia e koe? (M. 98). E whia aku mate? (M. 294). '
hikoi'
hinaun. Elaeocarpus dentatus, a tree. Whinau-puka, Elaeocarpus hookerianus, a tree.  '
1.v.i. Whistle. E oho nga atua whio (M. 408).2.n. Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus, blue duck; sometimes called whistling duck, = korowhio, whiorau'
n. Anthus novaeseelandiae, ground-lark, = kataitai, pihoihoi whaioia whioioiv.t. Shake, brandish, wave about see pioioi'
n. Zosterops lateralis, blight bird. = motengitengi, pihipihi, poporehe, tauhou.'
n. Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus, blue duck. = whio'
hioren. Tail of animals. He kuri toroherohe mai ana te whiore (T. 26).'

1.v.t. Twist, plat. Kei te muru whanake, kei te whiri taura (T. 150). Ka whiria he taura hei whitikiranga ki te taiki (T. 154).2.Use a certain trip in wrestling. Whiria ki te waewae kia hinga.3.n. Plaited hem on the upper edge of a cloak. Whiri o Raukatauri, a square plait of eight strands; also Asplenium flaccidum, Lycopodium billardieri, and other ferns. whiringan. Plaited hem. Ko nga mahunga o Paoa, kino iho, na te whiringa o te whanake i whakakino (T. 193).   = 3, above. whakawhiri1.v.t. Decimate a tribe by picking them off one by one.2.Fold the hands behind the back, as a person when tapu, who does not feed himself. whiriwhiriv.t. 1.Weave, plat. Whiriwhiri takue kete, ko Maunanea.2.Select, choose. Ko aku tangata kua oti te whiriwhiri (W.M. viii, 74).'
n. Flock, of certain birds. He whiri koko. He whiri, he kato taua (J. ix, 136).'
n. Strength.'

hirinaki1.v.i. Lean, slant, slope. Whirinaki kau au nga pou wharekura o Otuwhare ra (S. 78).2.n. Wooden buttress at the back of the upright slabs in the walls of a whare. (J. v, 147) whakawhirinaki1.v.i. Lean against anything.2.Trust in, depend on.3.v.t. Make fast, secure. Me whakawhirinaki ki etahi rakau e taki-tu nei nga taura (T. 159). see naki'
n. The fifth month of the Maori year. (Tu.) = Te Rima o Kopu of Ngati Awa'
n. The sixth month of the Maori year. (Tu.) = Whitianaunauof Ngati Awa.'
n. Gerygone igata, grey warbler. = riroriro'
n. Large basket. I tukua ki a matou tatahi whiriua, he inanga (Hae. 127).'
a. Lean, unproductive, especially of poor soil.'

1.a. Evil, bad. He ahurangi ranei koe, he whiro ranei?—He atua whiro a Rona.2.n. Proper name of a malevolent atua, the personification of evil, and of darkness and death.Me huahua taua ki te wai kohua kia oma ai a Whiro (M. 281).3.The moon on the first day.'

v.t. Sweep away. Kei whiroa au e te ia o Te Wairoa tuku atu ai. whakawhiro1.n. A charm repeated over a burning brand which was thrown into the sea with the object of making a gale clear up.Te whakawhiro o Mateoro (M. 155).2.v.t. Affect by such a charm.Me te ao mauru e whi te whakawhiro, kia whiti ki te tonga-paraki, he hau roki moana (M. 157). whirowhiro1.v.i. Whirl, swirl, as an eddy in a stream see tawhiro2.n. Podiceps rufopectus, dabchick or little grebe. = taihoropi, taratimoho, tokitoki, totoipio, etc.'
n. Pachyptila desolata, dove prion (dove petrel or whale-bird). = totorore'
hirokia. Lean, emaciated.'

a. Firm, secure, fast. Te moenga te whita, te moenga te au. whiwhita1.a. Quick, ready, zealous. Takatu ka whita a Te Aowera ki te haere ki te whawhai.2.v.t. Fasten, lash. Used of fastening a hook to the line.3.n. Lashing for binding a hook to the line. whitawhitaa. Eager, urgent, quick, brisk. Used of a fire burning well. Nei ka noho, me he ahi au te tahuna, whitawhita rawa ake (M. 99).'
