n. Prepared fibre of Phormium tenax, especially that from the variety called takikau or tihore. Tu kuku ana au te whitau i te repo (M. 146).'

1.v.i. Cross over, reach the opposite side. Na ka whakawhiti a Kupe i te moana o Raukawa, a ka whiti (T. 109).2.Change, turn. Me te ao mauru, e whi te whakawhiro kia whiti ki te tonga-paraki (M. 157).   Whiti tau rawa ake, ka mate nga kumara. Whiti ra runga, be inverted, be contrary. Ka kiia ko matou ki te moana, na ka whiti ra runga anake, ko ratou ka riro ki te moana.  3.v.t. Pass through. Ka whiti te tae te papa o te iramutu (Pi. 175, 2).4.Turn over, prise, as with a lever. Ka tikina te titoki hei whiti, ara hei whakaara ki runga; e popoki ana hoki te riu o te waka ki raro.—Katahi ka whitia e te iwi ra te kahararo, ka pokia te kaharunga.5.Change. Tunui ki te po whitia mai ki te ao na (M. 369). whakawhiti1.v.t. Convey across.2.Exchange.3.Cross over. Hei kawe i au nga whaka-whitinga o Whangaroa i runga (M. 206).4.Set about crossing. Na ka whakawhiti a Kupe i te moana o Ruakawa, a ka whiti (T. 109).5.n. Sail for a canoe. Ka rere mai te tuakana, tapahia ana te rahiri ka motu, ka whakaarahia te whakawhiti rawhara (M.M. 185).6.Return present.7.The carved boss or check at the end of the handle of a mere, to which the tau, or thong, was attached; also applied to a similar boss which was sometimes carved halfway down the handle of a paddle or of a pouwhenua.'

1.v.i. Shine. E whiti, e te ra, maene ki te kiri (M. 250). Ka whiti te atarau (M. 396).   So ra whiti (generally one word), sunrise, east. Whiti-te-ra, an expression of contempt: The wretch! Upoko! upoko! whiti-te-ra! (M. 72).2.v.t. Shine upon. Ko uta nei whitikia ai e te ra (T. 20).3.n. East. Roua ki whiti, roua ki tonga (M. 222). see rawhiti'

1.v.i. Start, be alarmed. Ka whiti to manawa (M. 33).   Whitiana taku poho i to karanga see kowhiti2.Spring, leap. Ka kitea te inanga i reira e whiti ana.3.Awake. Haramai nei, whakaoho rawa i taku moe, kia whiti rere (S. 86). Whakarehu rawa iho he wairua mongina, whiti rere rawa ake ka hewa kei te ao (M. 15). Te pa mai to waha kia whiti rere ake taku mauri ora ki runga (M. xcix).4.n. Alarm, shock. Ka tumeke, ka mataku, ka pa te whiti ki roto ki tona ngakau.5.Spring of a trap, made by bending over a wand of wood. Te whiti o te rore see tawhiti6.Hoop see mowhiti7.A species of earthworm. Called also toke whiti.8.a. Sudden, startling. Mana te ringa whiti (Let him strike the first blow). whitiwhitin. 1.Grasshopper, locust, see kapakapa, mowhitiwhiti2.A light rude fence of sticks; probably only when inserted as bows in the ground.'

1.v.t. Relate, recite. Ka hoki mai te tira, ka mea te tangata o te kainga, “Whitia te korero” (P. 104).   Used also of reciting karakia.2.Affect by recitation of a charm, bewitch. Hoatu, whitia ki te Poutama, ki te whiti a Rangahua.3.n. Verse, division, section of a song or karakia. Kua wareware etahi whiti e enei karakia ‖ S. ii, 52.4.Charm, incantation. Ko te whiti a Poutama, he karakia; ko ona putanga he kea, he whewhe, he patito, he aha.—E ai te whiti taua nau, e Te Kahika, he tiki mai tahau, he hura ra i te pohane (S.).'
n. The sixth month of the Maori year. (Ngati Awa.) = Whiringa-rangi'
v.t. Grasp a person''s aura or bewitch him. Kei whitihoro koe i tau hau (J. liii, 40).'
n. A downward blow delivered with the blade of the taiaha from the popotahi guard.'

1.v.t. Tie, bind. Ka whitikiria e ia te taura ki nga huruhuru o Kearoa (M. ix). Ka whiria he taura hei whitikiranga ki te taiki (T. 154).2.Gird, gird on. Whitikia to kakahu, i te ata ka whanake (M.M. 178).3.Hold, retain. Kahore he kaniwha (o te maka) hei whitiki i te kauae o te ika (Tr. vii, 41).4.v.i. Gird oneself. Whitiki, hapainga ki te tiki i to tatou matua (T. 200).   I te ata po ano e whitiki ana te ope ra.5.n. Belt, girdle. Ka tango ia i tona whitiki, me tona maro whero (T. 97).6.A kind of eel.'
n. New moon.'
a. Flapping, writhing. He ika whitirua (A fish flapping as it dies). He taringa whitirua koe (Used to an inattentive person) (P. 28).'
n. Dwarf see wheto'
1.v.t. Tie up.2.v.i. Be tied up.E whitoki mai ra te poaka  see hotiki'

num. 1.Seven, seventh. Hokowhitu, of an indefinite number of persons, band, force. E takoto tonu ana te hokowhitu o Whakatau-potiki (T. 41).   Used also adverbially, in a body, in force. Haere ake hokowhitu te kaitiki i a Paoa (T. 200). Katahi ka peke te hokowhitu ra, hokowhitu, hokowhitu atu ki tawahi o te awa (T. 41).2.Elliptically, seventh month. E tuku ra, e, te waikohu o te whitu (S. ii, 83).'

1.v.t. Throw, fling. Ka whiua hoki taku matau ki te wai (T. 21).2.Put, place. E whiu ana te wahie ki te whare (T. 145).   Whiua te kai ma te manuhiri. Whiu ke, divert. He tangata toutou koe, whakaaturia mai ana e koe to taonga, a whiua ketia ake.3.Plant. Kei te whiu riwai a Te Wainohu.4.Drive, cause to go. Whiua taua ki waho.5.Collect, assemble. Ka tae ki reira katahi ka whiua nga tangata; ka korerotia e taua wahine ra (J. iii, 100).6.Whip, chastise. He aha tau ka whiu nei i to tamaiti?7.Kill. Katahi ano a Manaia ka tuketuke atu i tana tamaiti kia rere ki te whiu i te mataika (T. 119).   No te panga o tana patu ki te tangata tuatahi i whiua ra e ia (ib.).8.v.i. Be gathered together. E ahiahi kau iho ana ano, ehara, e whiu ana te tangata whenua (T. 167).9.Turn or bend suddenly, toss. Ka hanga he tari ka hoatu ka potaria ki tona upoko, a ka whiu te kaki, kihai rawa i mau (T. 33).10.n. A certain throw in wrestling.11.A species of eel whiungan. Plaited border of a cloak. whakawhiu1.v.t. Oppress, afflict.2.n. A kind of fishing net. whiwhiuv.i. 1.Keep aloof. He tangata whiwhiu koe i waho o tenei mahi.2.Take flight, start up. Kihai te manu nei i whiwhiu, no te motunga i te mahanga i whiwhiu kino ai (M. 164). whiuwhiu1.v.i. Wag, whisk. E whiuwhiu ana te hiore o te kuri. Te whiuwhiu taku tatari (M. 380).2.n. Layers of toetoe overlapping one another on the ridge of a house.'
pt. Satisfied with food, surfeited.Ka whiu au. Ka whiu te upoko, my head aches (Ta. fiu)'

1.v.t. Wind round, fasten.2.Measure out the plan of a whare.3.Wrap round. Tauia nei te makura, ka whiwhi, ka rawe au, ka mau (K.). Tana ko te kore e whiwhia, tana ko te kore e rawea (J. iii, 10).4.a. Entangled. Aua e hoatu te aho ki te tamaiti kei whiwhi.5.pt. Possessed of, having acquired. Ka whiwhi ia ki tona hoa haere. He tangata momoe, he tangata mangere, e kore e whiwhi ki te taonga (P.).6.n. Fat covering the entrails. whiwhingan. 1.Circuit, boundary. Kei te whiwhinga o te rangi (J. ix, 206).2.Act or process of laying out the plan of a whare. I te timatanga o te hanganga whare he mea karakia te whiwhinga, he mea karakia te pounga o nga pou. whakawhiwhiv.t. 1.Wind round, fasten. Kua mau ke nga taura te whakawhiwhi ki nga rakau (T. 159).2.Give, present. Ka whakawhiwhia mai ki a ia te patu pounamu … me ia aho hoki, ka whakawhiwhi i tana ki te rangatira o te pa ra (T. 120). He whakawhiwhinga na to matua, koia i rawe ai (M. 243). whiwhiwhi1.a. Entangled. E wai e taea te kupenga whiwhiwhi? (P.).2.v. Adhere as fat. Me te ngako e whiwhiwhi ana ki nga whekau.'
n. A fish.'
see whita'
see whiu'
